loans.use: To purchase seeds and nutrients necessary for the production of peppers

loans.name: Farzana's Group

texts.en:
Farzana lives with her family in Multan, Pakistan, a city of tombs and holy places. She helps her husband in his business of selling milk. She is also a good mother who is bringing up her children very well. They both get up early and get milk from their buffalo. Then her husband goes to milk shops to sell it. In this way they generate income for their family.  

Presently, they have one buffalo, but it has started giving less milk. As inflation is increasing day by day, one buffalo is insufficient for meeting their financial expenses.  Therefore, Farzana has applied for a loan from Asasah so they will be able to buy another buffalo so they can sell its milk to more customers and increase their profits.  Earning more income will help them improve their standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for milking

loans.name: Mrs. Sokkhoeurn Kem Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sokkhoeurn K. is a village bank president who has been selected by twelve members located in Veal village in Kandal province. Each of the members will use a portion of their loan for different purposes, to improve their businesses. Mrs. Sokkhoeurn K. was born in 1972. She is a farmer who owns one-hectare of land to cultivate rice to sell, to support her family. She is a pig breeder too. Now she has some problems because her pigs are too small to sell. So to improve breeding pigs, Mrs. Sokkhoeurn K. is applying for a loan to buy pig food. With rest of the loan, she wants to buy rice to make white wine to start a new business. She is a widow with three children, one is a construction worker, another one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the third is attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy pig food.

loans.name: Mansab's Group

texts.en:
Mansab lives with her family in Multan, Pakistan, which is famous for its tombs and holy places. She is a housewife who is playing her role as a good wife and kind mother. 

Her husband drives an auto rickshaw which is their only source of income. He drives his rickshaw from 9am to 7pm. He goes to different areas in search of customers, and this keeps his rickshaw working for ten continuous hours. Now the rickshaw needs maintenance; otherwise, its engine will seize up.
 
Mansab has applied for a loan from Asasah which will be used for overhauling and maintaining her husband’s rickshaw. A newly maintained rickshaw will help him make more money because he will be able to work for greater periods of time and can work more efficiently.

loans.use: To repair her husband's rickshaw

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mrs. Phalla Sok Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eight people make up a village bank loan and they live in Veal village, in Kandal province. Mrs. Phalla S. is a village bank president, selected by the other members, who will each use a portion of the loan for different purposes. She is 36 years old. Her position is a farmer who owns a 1.5 hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family's costs of living. Now she has a problem because it is time to grow rice, but she does not have enough money to prepare the land. So to improve production, Mrs. Phalla S. is asking for a loan to do farming. Her husband, Mr. Bouch BO., is a construction worker. She is a mother of four children: two are construction workers, one is studying in the local public school, and the youngest one is two years old.

loans.use: To do farming.

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhum K., aged 57, operates her own small business selling various vegetables. Arising early in the morning, she travels to where the vegetable are sold in bulk, making her purchases and then hurrying to retail them in the local busy market, thereby earning enough money to cover her family's living expenses.

Chhum K. has a life partner in her husband, who appears on the right in the photo. He lost a limb during the civil war and currently works planting crops on his own farmland. Married many years, the couple is blessed with four children, one of whom is now married. Chhum K.’s husband wants to generate extra income as a taxi driver, so she is now requesting a loan to purchase a motorcycle with an attached trailer to enable him to start the service.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle with an attached trailer.

loans.name: Mumtaaz's Group

texts.en: Mumtaaz is a housewife whose husband operates a Punjabi food stall called Dahi Bhaley.  Both residents of Multan Pakistan for the past 20 years, her husband wants to buy more ingredients for his food stall for which Mumtaaz bibi is now requesting a loan from Asasah. By enabling her husband to sell larger quantities of food and add more products such as samosas, a very popular item,  Mumtaaz is hopeful that the loan will assist her family in improving their lives.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for Punjabi food stall

loans.name: Rukhsana Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana perveen lives in Multan the city of tombs and saints places in Pakistan. 

Multan is very famous for its embroidered clothes as well, Rukhsana perveen is also attached with the same profession. She is earning a good amount of income every month but she wants to further increase her income, because her children are growing older and their needs are increasing. So constant improvement is needed in the business in order to fulfill the needs of the family and to have a good standard of living. 

For that purpose Rukhsana perveen has applied for a loan from Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan). She will buy an embroidering machine with the loan money and will hire a worker to assist her. 

She is hopeful that these steps will help in improving her business and will grow her monthly income to a satisfactory level.

loans.use: to buy an embroidering machine

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia L. is a 38 year old married woman who supports her family by engaging in a general store. She also has 7 tricycles for rent as an additional business. She lives in Barangay Punta Tagda, Zone 5 Hinigaran, Negros Occidental with her husband and their 2 children. The children are 9 and 15 years old and are currently going to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1998 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and tricycle rental business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP35,000.

Amelia is now borrowing PHP40,000 so that she can use the additional capital for her general store and to purchase an additional tricycle. This will be her 16th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Amelia aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her general store and to purchase an additional tricycle.

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran is the wife of M. J., who sells fruits on the four-wheeled cart in different areas of the community. They live in Multan, city of sweetmeats in Pakistan with their children. 

Sughran runs a boutique in her home to financially support her husband. 

She has applied for a loan for the expansion of her husband’s business. He will buy more seasonal fruits to resell. She hopes that investment in her husband’s business will help him earn a better income; she wants to use a part of that profit to enhance her boutique business as well, which will help them in improving their standard of living.

loans.use: to buy seasonal fruits for resale

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita S. is a 48 year old married woman who supports her family with her general store business. She lives in Hda. Bubog, Talisay City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their 4 school-aged children.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP4,000.

Rita is now borrowing PHP23,000 to use as additional working capital. This will be her 15th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP23,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Rita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma D. is a 57-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Water Lily Zone 10, Talisay City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their child, who is currently attending school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 12,000.

Alma is now borrowing Php 15,000 so that she can use it as additional working capital for her general store. This will be her fourth cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Alma aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Rysbubu's Group

texts.en: Rysbubu S., 46, is the leader of this group. Her husband provides welding services at the thermal power station. They have five children: two daughters and three sons. In 1986 Rysbubu moved from the city to the village and, since that moment, she began to breed livestock. In the beginning she had four farm animals and now there are about twenty. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase five farm animals in order to increase the number of her livestock. In the future she wants to save some money to contribute to her son’s wedding. Toktobu D., 35, is the treasurer of the group. Her husband works as a concrete worker at the thermal power station. They have two daughters and a son and all of them study at school. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 6,000 soms, Toktobu bought four farm animals and began to breed livestock. When her husband is free, he helps her with that activity. With money received from the loan Toktobu wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. Tynarbek T. is 58 and married. Thirty years ago he bought three cattle and started to breed them. Then, having success in that activity, he sold some cattle and bought a beehive. Since then he has been engaged in both activities: cattle breeding and beekeeping. Now he wants to obtain a loan to purchase more cattle for breeding. Uulbu A. is 50 and married. She owns a piece of land where she cultivates different fruits and vegetables. Also, her husband helps her with cattle breeding. They have been doing this for thirty years. And now, Uulbu has applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more cattle for breeding. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase five farm animals to increase the number of her livestock

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim, a very caring lady and a citizen of Multan, Pakistan, famous for its sweetmeats and sacred places, has owned and lived in a small two-room house with her family for over 15 years. She does domestic sewing in order to bear the financial burden with her husband, a milk shop employee who earns a small income by selling milk.

As the inflation rate steadily increases, their earnings become insufficient to meet the family's financial needs. Therefore, Shamim is requesting a loan from Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan) to buy a buffalo for her husband so he can start his own milk-selling business, hopeful that the enterprise will enhance her family's earnings, enabling them to overcome their financial problems.

loans.use: To purchase a buffalo to start a milk-selling business

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans is 24 years old. He is married and has no children. He is a hardworking farmer from Nyamira town in Western Kenya.

Evans has been practising mixed farming for 5 years. His products are maize, beans and bananas which he sells to the local market. He also operates a shop in the same area. 

His biggest challenges in farming are the limited market for his products, limited land for expansion and lack of farm implements and fertilizers.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 45,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to purchase a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for sale. The extra income from this loan will help improve the family's living standards.

In the future, he plans to purchase additional land to expand his farming activities.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sirochidin

texts.ru: Суфиев Сирочидин проживает в районе Дж. Руми. Возраст, 39 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, занимается торговлей. Сам Сирочидин имеет высшее образование по специальности "Педагог". По профессии проработал 2 года. Сейчас он занимается торговлей. У него магазин, где он продает продукты питания. Этим видом бизнеса занимается уже 3 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Sirochidin S. lives in the J. Rumy region. He is 39 years old, married and has four children. His wife does sales. Sirochidin has high education and is a teacher by profession. He has worked in the field for two years. Right now he is also in sales. He has a store where he sells food. He has been in this business for three years. He is taking the loan to increase volume of sales.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales

loans.name: Kouser Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Kouser perveen is very confident that an investment in her husband's business will help it greatly, because she knows that he is very hard working person but the problem he faces is the lack of capital to invest in his business. 

Kousar perveen has applied for a loan from Asasah which will help her husband improve his scrap business by adding more scrap. Kousar perveen lives in Multan and does embroidery work to support her family financially. 

She is very hopeful that she will be able to help her children complete their education by increasing her household income through investment in the business.

loans.use: Purchase scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda M. is a married woman who lives in Cogon III, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns a living by operating a fish vending business.  Her husband Romeo, who is 60 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 35 and 37 years old. 

Erlinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired to have something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Erlinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, lifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 18th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to improve her business so that she can continue to save up for future house improvement. Erlinda M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital.

loans.name: Avelino

texts.en:
61-year-old Avelino C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is married to Annie and has a 21-year-old child. Avelino owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Avelino has been engaged in his business for over 40 years already.

In 2007, Avelino joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Avelino has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Avelino is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Avelino from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is married with seven children, all of them in school, and also looks after her granddaughter. She sells charcoal in Kyebando Nsooba Kawempe division from her home. She has been in this business for six years. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of charcoal. Her business is wholesale only. Sarah buys charcoal from Masindi and sells to local people and her neighbors. She works seven days a week and also owns a poultry farm. Sarah’s main business challenges are transportation and the rainy season which makes village roads impassable. Her future aspiration is to develop her self in all aspects of life like educating her children up to university level and owning a delivery van. Sarah's greatest monthly expense is food and medication. She lives in, and owns, a three-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 41 years old. Beverly is married to Rudy and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Beverly owns three hectares of land where she plants and harvests rice for sale. When free of farming duties, she also cooks food that she sells around her community. Beverly has been engaged in her business for over 17 years.

In 2007, Beverly joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Beverly is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She also plans to buy a pig she could raise. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Beverly from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and a pig to raise

loans.name: Amna Bano's Group

texts.en: Amna bano is the wife of I. A. and lives in the city of Multan, Pakistan, with her husband and children. She runs a boutique in her house to support her family. She displays her stitched and embroidered clothes in her boutique which attracts more customers. Her clientele base is made up of her neighbors and relatives. The earned income helps her to pay for the utilities. Now she wants to expand her business in the market as well. She has applied for a loan from Asasah, to invest in her boutique. With the loan she will buy material in bulk such as clothes, beads, and thread. This material helps her to make more dresses to introduce her work in the market. She hopes that by doing this she can attract more customers which will greatly enhance her income.

loans.use: Purchase materials for her boutique

loans.name: Susana's Group

texts.en:
Susana C. is from the village of Misom Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old and the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Millions. Susana is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Susana sells coconuts and has a "sari-sari" store selling products such as eggs, noodles, sugar, and biscuits. Susana has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month. 

In 2009, Susana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2009 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Susana is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Susana from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

texts.en:
Everlyn T. is from the village of Misom Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Everlyn owns a clothing business. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2800 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Everlyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Everlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Everlyn is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Everlyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Saing

texts.en:
Mrs. Saing P. is 39 years old and a resident of Phnom Penh City, where she has established a small family home with other members. Her husband provides a little income to support the family’s living expenses by driving a ferry boat. The couple is blessed with three young kids who are enrolled in the local primary school.

Saing P. built a workshop located along the street where she sells inventory to people who are passersby. She sells items like cane goods, snack food, and some sweets both retail and wholesale.

Saing P. wants to decorate her shop because she hopes it may attract more clients. Then she wishes to accumulate more inventory for her store. In order to make that possible, she decided to ask for a Kiva loan of $1,000 through HKL.

loans.use: To decorate her workshop and accumulate more inventory

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
46-year-old Elsie N. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married and has an 8-year-old child.

Elsie owns and operates a business raising crops. She owns a hectare (2.5 acres) of land where she plants and harvests rice crops that she sells at the market. She also raises two pigs. Elsie has been engaged in her business for over ten years now.

Elsie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Elsie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure, and also additional pigs. This loan will be her ninth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure, and additional pigs

loans.name: Rubilyn's Group

texts.en: Rubilyn M. is from the village of Magcamiguing, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Rubilyn is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Tulips. Rubilyn is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Rubilyn operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products, such as sugar, milo (milk beverage), biscuits, shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Rubilyn has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month from it. In 2009, Rubilyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rubilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Rubilyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Rubilyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Maribelou

texts.en:
Maribelou T., from the village of Southern Pob. Plaridel Misamis Occidental, is 38 years old and separated from her spouse. To make a living, Maribelou owns and operates a specialized retail store selling clothing and shoe products, lotion, cologne, etc. in the local community. Engaged in her business for over six years, she earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Maribelou joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 25000 PHP from GDMPC that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting a new loan, her fourth, of 50000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. Maribelou plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali A. Abeileh is a young man from Jericho. He is a Palestinian National Authority employee. Ali is responsible for a big family that consists of his wife, parents, sister and brother. His salary from the Palestinian National Authority doesn't cover household expenses.

Ali's father owns a piece of land. Five years ago, Ali and his father started growing vegetables and distributing them to the neighboring market to generate a second income to support their big family. Ali took a $1,500 loan to purchase an agricultural pesticide sprayer, because the hot weather for which Jericho is known is good weather for worms to grow and harm plants.

Ali, who appears in the photograph, works the land after his working hours. Then, early each morning, he distributes the plant yields to the neighboring market.

loans.use: Purchase an agricultural sprayer

loans.name: Quirwin

texts.en: Quirwin E. is from the village of Acad, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 38 years old. Quirwin is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Quirwin raises crops. The main source of income for his business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Quirwin has been engaged in his business for more than two years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Quirwin joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Quirwin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Quirwin is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the third loan taken out by Quirwin from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a single mother. She had three children and all of them died. She now takes care of the grandchildren from her late children. Mary resides in and owns a four room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food and medication.

Mary used to have a pub but changed her business enterprise to a retail shop, which she has been running for a few months. Her customers are the local people and her neighbors. She works seven days a week. Mary’s business challenges include seasonality and transportation of merchandise from Kikuubo to her shop in Nsooba. Mary wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, rice, boxes of soap and cooking oil. Besides this business, Mary also gets some income from rental rooms. She hopes to see her business grow big and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise such as sugar, cooking oil, rice and soap

loans.name: Phrom

texts.en: Mrs. S., 54, is a low-income earner living in the best territory of Phnom Penh, which is good for economic activities. S. is widowed; her husband died of senility years ago. She has four children: one is married and the other three are single. All of her children work in different occupations. To earn her daily income, S. sells traditional cakes, vegetables, and some fruits at the local market. She typically earns approximately $3 per day to cover the family’s living expenses. Since her current job is a profitable one, S. desires to sustain its growth by requesting a Kiva loan for assistance.

Eduard B. is from the village of Sto. Nino, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 25 years old, married and has 2 very young children. Eduard owns and operates a business offering motor transport services. Eduard has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from it..

In 2010, Eduard joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eduard is requesting his first loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair an existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz lives in the city of Multan, which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. She and her husband have been involved in a milk selling business for over three years. They are both very hardworking and brave people. They have the courage to fight against bad circumstances. They overcome their problems by staying together. They get milk from their buffalo; Shahnaz sells it to her neighbors and her husband sells it to milk shops. They have both obtained good reputations among their customers.

Shahnaz has applied for a loan from Asasah / Kiva to expand their dairy business. They will buy another buffalo with the loan. They are hopeful that it will make their family life comfortable by increasing their income and providing a larger amount of milk.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for the dairy business

loans.name: Gemalyn

texts.en:
Gemalyn D. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 39 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Gemalyn owns and operates a farming business, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Gemalyn has been engaged in her business for over 20 years now.

Gemalyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Gemalyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn C., 45, is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married to Teodoro and has one child, who is 9. To make a living, Jocelyn raises crops. She currently owns a hectare of land, where she plants and harvests rice crops for sale. She also raises a sow and two piglets. She has been engaged in her business for more than three years and hopes for her business to grow. In 2007, Jocelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI, a Kiva partner. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She will also buy feeds for her pigs. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Jocelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About CEVI Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Davaajargal

texts.en:
Davaajargal V., age 42, lives with her son in Uvurhangai province. They live in her own traditional housing tent called a ger. In 2003, she moved from Taragt sub province and purchased a container in which she kept food products. She is a teacher and her living conditions are good. Depending on sales, Davaajargal makes food-procurement trips two to four times a month. Bread, pastry and cookies are supplied by the manufacturers. 

Her personality is polite, and she seems to be good at calculating and estimating. She wants to have her own food store and work in her profession of teaching or accounting. 

She is requesting a 3,400,000 Mongolia tugriks (MNT) loan to purchase food products at wholesale prices from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Mul

texts.en:
Mrs. L., 36, is a humble villager living Kompong Cham Province. She resides with other family members in a wooden house. She is married with two school-aged kids, who are dependent on her. 

To earn a living, L. plants a potato crop and she also harvests and sells the mature crop to a private company for a profit. She normally receives help from her husband, who works on the farm with her. The approaching rainfall season is good for growing, but L. has no capital to use on her field. Thus, she requests a Kiva loan to clean up her farmland and then begin planting potatoes on it.

loans.use: To clean up her farmland and begin planting potatoes on it

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine L., 50 years old, is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married to Franklin and has seven school-aged children. Josephine owns and operates a business raising crops. She and her husband till their land for rice crops and sell their harvest at the market. She also raises some chickens and hopes to acquire more chicken to raise. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-nine years now. In 2007, Josephine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seed, fertilizer, and other farm inputs. She also plans to buy additional chickens. This loan will be her ninth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer, chickens, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Balqees' Group

texts.en:
Balqees has lived in the city of Multan, Pakistan, for the past ten years. She is a housewife who takes care of her family by staying at home. Her husband is a rickshaw driver. He drives someone else’s rickshaw and receives an income not according to his struggle. This keeps him less energetic because he feels bad when he never completes the financial needs of his family.

Therefore, Balqees applied for a loan from Asasah to help him buy his own rickshaw so he can work with satisfaction and avoid paying the cost of renting one. This will enable him to work for more hours and also earn him more income.

loans.use: To purchase a rickhaw for her husband

loans.name: Ngoen

texts.en:
Mrs. S. is a young woman whose husband appears in the photo here. S. is a mother who takes care of a baby who is not yet enrolled in school. Her husband is a firewood seller who obtains his firewood from the forest.

S. raises poultry out of her home to earn a living. She doesn’t have a stall for her poultry and she proposes to build one; thus, S. would like to ask a loan in order to construct a stall for her poultry.

loans.use: To construct a stall for her poultry

loans.name: Lenida

texts.en: 44-year-old Lenida P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married and has four adult children. Lenida owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She currently owns three hectares (7.5 acres) of rice field and has been engaged in her business for over three years now. Lenida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lenida is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her ninth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Ork

texts.en:
Mrs. Ork N., 45, has a pig-raising skill that she learned from her grandparent and currently uses this knowledge to make a living. She has built a pigpen where she breeds many pigs and she also sells the pigs to a buyer when the pigs come to maturity.

Besides this, Ork N. and her husband take time to cultivate a rice crop for the propose of eating and selling as well. This approaching rainfall season is the best for growing and Ork N. is applying for a loan to plant rice crops.

Ork N. now has four children: one is married and three are single. Ork N. was not available when the photo taken so her daughter is pictured instead.

loans.use: To plant rice crops

loans.name: Vanna's Group

texts.en: This group loan has four people who live in Lekh Pir village in Kandal province. All members have selected Mr. Vanna C. as the group leader. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes, in order  to improve their businesses in the future. Mr. Vanna C. was born in 1966. He is a motorbike taxi driver who earns money to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Simorn Thouch, is a vegetable seller at a local market where she can also earn some money to support her family. Since his wife’s business is going well, she wants to expand it. So to improve this business, Mr. Vanna C. is applying for a loan to buy more vegetables to resell. He is a father of four children, one of whom is a chef, while another one is attending a local public school, and the others are helping his wife sell vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Leo

texts.en:
Leo B., 41, from the town of Sto. Niño, is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Leo has been planting and harvesting rice for sale for over 10 years now.

Leo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid his previous loan from CEVI, he is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be Leo's ninth loan from CEVI, and he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en: Nazia is wife of A. and lives in Multan, a city of sweetmeats in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over fifteen years. A very talented lady, Nazia operates her embroidered clothes business. She does this work to improve the living standard of her family. She takes orders from her neighbors and relatives and her good embroidery skills keep her customers coming back. She has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest in her business. With the loan she will buy materials in bulk such as clothes, beads, and threads. She is hopeful that she will be able to bring positive financial change to her family by increasing her business.

loans.use: Purchase embroidery materials

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia F., 49, is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married to Placido and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lucia has a hectare of land for planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also raises pigs, chickens and ducks. Lucia has been engaged in her business for over 21 years.

In 2007, Lucia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lucia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Lucia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 39 years old and married with four school-aged children. She owns a hectare of land where she plants and harvests rice for sale. She also has a portion of land where she plants vegetables that she sells at the market and is raising a pig for breeding. She has been doing these activities for more than 10 years.

Marietta joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marietta has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Marietta is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Marietta from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and sustain her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Merlie

texts.en: Merlie P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 54 years old, is widowed, and has two school-aged children. Merlie owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She hopes to be successful someday. In 2007, Merlie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Merlie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her ninth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.
