loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Mrs. Mao Bo Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has 26 people who live in Chamkar Ta Ngaet village in Kandal province. Mrs. Mao B. is the village bank president, selected by the other members who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their businesses. She is 50 years old. She is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land to grow crops to sell to support her family. Now, she has a problem because her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Mao B. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. She is a widow with two children, who are both helping her with the farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Samphas

texts.en: Mrs. Samphas L. is a villager in Lekh Pir village in Kandal province. She was born in 1987. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Tina Chan, is a security guard. Now, her problem is that she has not constructed her house yet. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Samphas L. is asking for a loan to continue building her new home. She is the mother of a child who is too small to work or study.

loans.use: To continue to build her new home.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 48 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children.

Nilda owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale.

Nilda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Nilda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her ninth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Sourn S., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

S. weaves Cambodian traditional silk for an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of about USD 1 per day to help cover the family expenses.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more raw silk to produce silk products to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy raw silk to produce more silk products to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Yorn Yoeurn Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eight people, who live in Chrolong village in Kandal province, make up this village bank loan. All of the members have selected Mrs. Yorn Y. as a village bank president. They will each use a portion of their loan for different purposes, to improve their businesses. Mrs. Yorn Y. is 37 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Sambath Kan, are vegetable sellers at their local market where they can earn some money to support their family. Since their business is going well she wants to expand. So, Mrs. Yorn Y. is seeking for a loan to buy more vegetables to resell. She is a mother of six children, four of whom are attending a local public school, while the others are too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Nub

texts.en:
Nub S., 54, is widowed and lives with her three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

S. weaves Cambodian traditional silk for an income of USD 5 per day. She is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase more raw silk to produce silk products to sell.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy raw silk to produce more silk products to sell

loans.name: Twekembe Development Group, Jinja

texts.en:
Highly spirited, 38-year-old N. Scovia has brought hard work and good customer relationship skills to bear in her three-and-a-half-year-old fish-selling business in Masese Landing Site, Jinja. In this time, she has zeroed in on the weak points associated with plying this kind of business and she has made commendable amends in her own right, with a framework of exemplary ideas that have significantly helped her in dealing with the many challenges that come with running a business of this nature.

This married mother of three has a self-assured attitude that she nurtured whilst still running her erstwhile grocery business. This has done her a good turn in her current business. She also ekes out side profits from her charcoal-selling business.

The future looks bright for Scovia on the basis of the aforementioned attributes. She currently makes profits to the tune of 30,000 shillings per week and she is cheerfully upbeat that her prospects will improve with this loan. With the auspices of this loan, she is looking at buying her own boat. This she says will reduce her operational costs as she won’t be buying fish any more.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat so that she can employ her own people to catch her fish

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 51 years old, is married, and has three children. Her oldest child is now aged 33.

Perla owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-nine years already.

Perla joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Perla is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs. This loan will be her ninth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Zaitoon Begum's Group

texts.en:
Zaitoon Begum has applied for a loan from Asasah for the growth of her business selling clothes. She lives with her family in Multan, a city famous for sweetmeats in Pakistan. She is an enthusiastic lady who enjoys doing her work. She purchases clothes from the nearby markets, because good fabrics are also a specialty of Multan city, and this is a benefit for those who are involved in the clothes selling business. 

Zaitoon Begum sells clothes in her community and to relatives and this generates profit for her family. She has been involved in this work for the past six years. With this loan, she will buy a better quality of clothes which she can sells at good profit.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Aem's Group

texts.en: In Angk Khlaeu village, in Kandal province, four members of this group loan have selected Mr. Aem U. as a group leader. Each of the members will use a portion of the loan for different purposes, with the goal of improving their businesses in the future. Mr. Aem U. is 36 years old. He is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land where he can grow crops to sell to support his family. Now his problem is it is time to grow crops but he does not have enough money to support the field. So to improve production, Mr. Aem U. is seeking for a loan to do farming this current year. His wife, Mrs. Kosorl Lou, is a seamstress in a garment factory. He is a father of four children, all attending the local public school.

loans.use: To do farming.

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en:
38-year-old Rosalyn B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married to Arnel and they have two children aged 17 and 18.

Rosalyn owns a hectare (2.5 acres) of field where she plants and harvests rice crops to sell. She also grows hogs for fattening. She has been engaged in her business for over eighteen years now and hopes that someday she will succeed in all her ventures.

Rosalyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Rosalyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure and also feed for her hogs. This loan will be her ninth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure and also feed for her hogs

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 39 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children.

Three years ago, Shirley invested in farming and continues to farm today. She plants and harvests rice crops that she sells at their local market. She says she is thankful for her farm because it helps provide for the increasing needs in her household.

Shirley joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Shirley is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure and also other farm inputs. This loan will be her ninth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, such as manure, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Srey Toch's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Toch P. is a group leader who has been selected by four members who are villagers in Krabau village, in Kandal province. Each of the members will use a portion of their loan for different purposes. Mrs. Srey Toch P. is 37 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Vey Tang, own a general store in the local village where they sell groceries to support their family. Since their business is going well they want to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Srey Toch P. is seeking for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. She is a mother of three children: two attend the local public school, while the youngest one is only six years old.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell.

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
Nulu is married with six children, all them in school, and also takes care of some additional family members. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent and school fees.

Nulu owns a charcoal store in Nalukolongo market and buys charcoal from delivery vans which get it from villages. Therefore, she doesn’t incur any transport costs. She has been in this business for twenty years and works seven days a week. She also earns some money from tailoring.

Nulu rents her store in Nalukolongo and pays monthly market dues. Her customers are the local people and her neighbors. She depends on this job to get a living. Her main business challenge is the rainy season because she works from a muddy place and this hinders her customers from reaching her.

Nulu plans to use the loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She is aspiring to see her business grow big and to start going directly to villages for charcoal. She joined MCDT to get additional capital for her business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita B. has been involved in farming for more than 21 years now. She is a 60-year-old married woman from the town of Sto. Niño. She has four grown-up children. Teresita plants and harvests rice crops that she sells in the local market. She owns her own carabao (water buffalo) that helps in her farming. She also raises some pigs and chickens.

Teresita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This will be her ninth loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Sa Khorn's Group

texts.en: This group loan is made up of four people who live in Prey Totueng village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sa Khorn P. is a group leader, selected by the other members who will each use a portion of their loan for different purposes. She is 55 years old. She owns a general store at her home where she can sell groceries to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Chork Heourn, is a farmer who owns a three-hectare plot of land where he can grow crops to sell to support his family. Although they both try to work hard, they earn little income. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Sa Khorn P. is applying for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of three children: one is a juice seller, while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
37-year-old Theresa M. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Theresa plants and harvests rice for sale. Theresa has been engaged in her business for over 11 years now.

Theresa joined CEVI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid previous loans from CEVI. Theresa is requesting her ninth loan, for 15000 PHP, which she will use to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Phally's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Phally S. is a group leader who has been selected by five people located in Khpob Veaeng village in Kandal province. All of the members of this group loan will use portion of the loan for different purposes with the goal of improving their businesses. Mrs. Phally S. was born 1962. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Oeurn Lor, is a construction worker. Now she has a problem in that her house is broken. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Phally S. is applying for a loan to fix her house. She is a mother of four children, two of whom are seamstresses in garment factory, while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To fix her house.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
32-year-old T. Patrick is a hardworker, as evidenced by the organised way his banana-selling business is operated. Unlike some of the other banana-selling business people in Karambi, Ibanda, who buy and later resell to customers in not so hygienic conditions, he plants and sells his own bananas in a clean environment. He has done this for the last fifteen years and as a result of his good persuasive skills and good organization, he has got himself a good ready market for his bananas at his stall in Karambi.

With this experience behind him, Patrick knows nothing can hinder him in his endeavor to expand. Among the challenges that have caused a threat to him in the course of operating this business, has been the ever-fluctuating local market price of bananas. He has relied on his resilience to get him through this, however.

At present, Patrick makes profits amounting to 120,000 shillings a week. This married father of four is hoping this loan will get him far, in terms of buying mulches and pesticides for his banana plantations.

loans.use: To buy mulches and pesticides for his banana plantations

loans.name: Ul

texts.en:
Ul C., 20, is married and resides with her husband and a young child in Takeo Province, Cambodia – an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. C. sells sugar cane juice and has an income of $3 US per day. Her husband is a blacksmith, earning about $6 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of $1,200 US to purchase more equipment to expand the blacksmith business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. C.'s mother appears in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy more equipment to expand a blacksmith business

loans.name: Sreyneat's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreyneat N. is the group leader of a four person group loan based in Preaek Samraong village in Kandal province. The group loan will be used for different purposes to improve the borrowers' businesses. 


Mrs Sreyneat Nheah is 28 years old. She is a food seller at the local market where she can earn some money to support her family. Now she has a problem because her store needs some repairs. She is asking for a loan to fix her store and to buy more food to resell. 


Her husband, Mr. Touch Nub, is employed at a printing company and gets a low salary with which to support his family. They have two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local public school, while the youngest is one year old.

loans.use: To fix her store

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah is married and has four children currently attending school. Hadjah rents a two-room house with access to electricity, but no piped water.  Her monthly expenses are school fees, rent for business, rent for residence and food.   

For 15 years, Hadjah has had a business selling African attires (Bitenge). She works 7 days a week and sells in both retail and wholesale. She buys African attires from shops on Nakivubo complex in Kampala city. She sells all types of attires ranging from Nigerian to Congolese attires. While her business is challenged by the risk of thieves, she aspires of going directly to Congo for attire and even selling on wholesale only. She plans to use the loan to buy more Bitenge (African attires) and rent the shop where she works from.

loans.use: To buy more African attires

loans.name: Bou

texts.en:
Bou S., 43, is married and resides with her husband and five children. They live in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. S. and her husband are farmers growing vegetables and earn an income of $3 USD/day to cover family expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of $1100 USD to purchase a motorbike for their children to commute work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
B. Emmanuel is a hardworking and an ever-optimistic 29-year-old married father of two kids aged between 23 and 10 years. He operates a growing grocery business in Kabura Ibanda, dealing in produce, especially maize.

With hard work and a business experience of five years, Emmanuel has managed to significantly sustain and improve his family’s welfare. As it appears, his future business chances are looking promising with close to 200,000 Ugandan shillings coming in monthly from his business.

Emmanuel is hoping for an even greater profit on getting this loan, as he anticipates he will be in position to buy more crops like cassava, beans and millet for his business. This will enable him to expand his business and also enable him to earn more revenue.

loans.use: To purchase other crops like millet and cassava

loans.name: Samorn

texts.en:
Samorn S., 30, is married and resides with her husband and two children. They live in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. S. is a farmer and earns an income of $2 USD per day. Her husband is a tuk-tuk driver and earns an income of $4 USD per day to help cover family expenses.

Samorn is requesting a loan of $1000 USD to purchase cows to help plow the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. Samorm appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To buy cows to help the rice field

loans.name: Hong

texts.en: Hong E., 41, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. E. sells food at a tourist place in the province for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a motor taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. E. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to operate his business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Sophea's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people who live in Preaek Anhchanh village in Kandal province. Mr. Sophea S. has been selected as the group leader. They will all use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 


Mr. Sophea S. is 29 years old. He is a motorbike taxi driver. He has a problem in that his motorbike is broken. To rectify this situation, he is applying for a loan to fix his motorbike. 


His wife, Mrs. Gnagn Sem, is a seamstress in a garment factory who gets a low salary with which to support her family. He has two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local public school, while the youngest is one year old.

loans.use: To fix his motorbike

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en: Byambasuren B. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Hovd province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her son attends a local middle school and her daughter goes to kindergarten. Byambasuren operates a retail business in her town. The family began the business in 2009 and since then they have been gaining experience. Her husband is a singer in the local culture center. She purchases food in bulk, such as candy, chewing gum, and soft drinks to sell by the piece. Byambasuren is a hardworking and optimistic person who has a plan to build her own house. She is requesting a 200,000-MNT loan to purchase a large amount of food and goodies.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok M., 49, is married and resides with her husband and six children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. M. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about USD 3 each per day to help cover the family expenses. Sok is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to run a tailor shop. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To open a tailor shop

loans.name: Tasleem Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Tasleem akhtar lives in the city Multan, Pakistan with her family.  A talented lady, Tasleem operates a clothes-selling business to financially support her husband. She purchases clothes from her nearby market and sells them to different areas of the community. Earlier she sold her clothes by going door to door in the community. Now they have become her good customers and her son delivers their orders to their houses. She has been in this business for over five years.  

She has applied for a loan from Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan) to invest the loan amount in her clothes selling business.  She is hopeful that the loan amount will help her to complete her orders on time for her customers.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for reselling

loans.name: Doljinsuren

texts.en: Doljinsuren L. is 48 years old and lives with her three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of  Mongolia. She and her family live in their own apartment. Her children, two daughters and one son, range in ages from 16 to 26 years old. Doljinsuren has been operating a clothing and shoes trade business in Narantuul Trade market in the city since 2002. She provides a variety of shoes to satisfy her customer's needs and imports them from China twice a month. She owns a stall in the market where she sells her products. After some years of positive growth with her business, she afforded her children tuition fees. Today the family enjoys a stable operation with the businesses and is focused on expanding their shoes trade business in the near future. The family lives in a two-room apartment in Ulaanbaatar city in Mongolia and the living conditions are good as well. She is a very modest person. Doljinsuren is requesting a 1,425,000 MNT loan to import products from Beijing, the capital city of China.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Prom

texts.en: Mr. Prom Y. is a middle-age man whose wife appears on the left in the photo. Prom Y. has been spending his life raising crops and pigs. This is a skill he learned from his grandparent when he was young. He is now married and has a school-aged kid. His wife works in the farm fields frequently alongside him. Prom Y. has been building a new stone house to live in for months, but the construction has been suspended for a while due to the lack of funds. This house requires many parts to complete. Prom Y. would like to borrow $1,200 to be used to purchase more housing accessories to continue building his new house. With any remaining cash from the loan, Prom Y. will plant a rice crop when the rainfall season comes.

loans.use: To purchase more housing accessories to build his house

loans.name: Mr. Mon Chae Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has eighteen people who live in Bang village in Kandal province. Mr. Mon C. is a village bank president, selected by the other members. They will all use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 


Mr. Mon C. is a village chief who earns a low salary with which to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Rum Phorn, is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice, not for sale, but to support her family. Now he has a problem because his wife’s field is infertile. Mr. Mon C. is, therefore, applying for a loan to buy fertilizer. He is the father of two children, one of whom is a construction worker, while the other is attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem V., 27, is married and resides with his wife and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. V. is employed to grow plants for an income of USD 3 per day. His wife is a garment factory worker, earning an income of about USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses. V. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a new motorbike to commute to work. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Mr. Sem P. has been spending his life cultivating crops. This is a skill he learned from his grandparent when he was young. He is now married and has four children who are going to school and work. His wife appears on the right in the photo. She works in the farm fields frequently alongside him. Growing crops is an annual action with which he has had great success. He is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. Sem P. is concerned that he doesn’t have a vehicle to deliver the mature crops to the market for sale, so he decided to look for assistance to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Ganchimeg

texts.en:
Ganchimeg C., age 46, lives with her three children in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent, called a ger, on a small plot of land which they own. Her two younger sons are both attend a middle school while the elder son is a student of a technology college. Ganchimeg's family is big and she lives with her three sons, two grandsons and a daughter-in-law.

Since 1990, Ganchimeg has been operating a clothing repair business at her home but now she is renting a small workplace in Harhoring, one of the biggest markets in Ulaanbaatar, making and selling a variety of clothing items. Her eldest son works in a construction company and earns 300,000 MNT per month as well.

Oyunchimeg has many plans to expand her business in the future. She also plans to build a house for her eldest son and his family. Ganchimeg is a hardworking and generous woman. She is requesting an 850,000 MNT loan to purchase construction and sewing materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her business

loans.name: Lung

texts.en:
Lung S., 47, is widowed and resides with her two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

S. is a farmer and also sells groceries at home for an income of USD 3 per day. She is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase cows to help plow her rice field.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy cows to help plow her rice field

loans.name: Rasheeda Begum's Group

texts.en:
Rasheeda begum does embroidery work to support her family financially. She lives in Multan where the cost of living is very high.

Rasheeda makes embroidered dresses to order and earns a good profit on the completion of each dress. The profit gives her courage to move her business forward towards success. Earlier, she received orders from her relatives but now her work is acknowledged by her neighbors as well. She earns 500 PKR profit on each dress, which helps her to pay for the utilities.

Rasheeda has applied for a loan from Asasah to buy embroidery material such as clothes, beads and thread in bulk. The material in bulk will help her to make more embroidered dresses and improve her chances of making more sales and income.

loans.use: To purchase embroidery material in bulk to make more embroidered dresses

loans.name: Ganchimeg

texts.en:
Ganchimeg J. is 31 years old and lives with her husband and a daughter in a ger, the traditional Mongolian housing tent, in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her daughter, age 6, goes to a kindergarten while her husband runs a consumer goods trading business.

Ganchimeg used to work as a knitter in the Gobi Cashmere factory of Mongolia and now she is self-employed, making a variety of knitted and woven products in her small factory and selling them in the western provinces and the countryside. Her husband operates a stable shoe-trading business in Harhorin, one of the biggest markets in Ulaanbaatar.

Currently, Ganchimeg wants to ensure the stability of her business and expand her small factory. She is requesting a 1,800,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more fabrics, knitting machine spare parts, and equipment for her business.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics, knitting machine spare parts, and equipment for her business

loans.name: Kanyogoga Bakyala Tukore Group, Mubende

texts.en:
40-year-old Justine N. has, as a result of her strong resilience, operated her retail shop for the last fifteen years in a not-so-profitable area in Kanyogoga, Mubende. What has counted has been her determination to succeed in addition to her already mentioned resilience in the face of financial uncertainties. 

Justine began this business with savings from her earlier bar business. In a week, this married woman, who is also a mother to six children, makes 40,000 shillings. This, though little, has helped her stay in her business. The support of friends as also helped. She also relies on earnings from her small produce-selling business.

With this loan, Justine wants to purchase more domestic retail items that are liked and bought on a regular basis by many people in her locality: items like sugar, salt and soap.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items like sugar and soap

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita A., 48, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Enrique A., a driver, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Amelita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.

To ensure the success of her business, Amelita would like to apply for a PHP 39,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying groceries, toiletries and beverages to replenish and maintain her current inventory.

Amelita dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to replenish and maintain her current inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase sheep

loans.name: Ganhuyag

texts.en: Ganhuyag C. is a 46- year- old single mother who lives with her two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Ganhuyag operates a clothing making and repair business in a rented basement and sells out of a stall at Narantuul, the biggest market in the city. She and her sister started the business in 1994 and since then, she has been gaining much experience in the business and the variety of products has been enlarged earning a good profit. Ganhuyag has found success in her operation and has used her earnings to support her family. Ganhuyag is an honest and hardworking woman who hopes to continue her success by growing her business and employing two tailors at the workplace in the future. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase two sewing machines and more material for her business.

loans.use: To purchase two sewing machines

loans.name: Tsongo

texts.en:
U. is a married woman with two children. One child attends school and the other one is preschool age.. Her spouse is a driver by profession and he meets the family basic needs out of his earnings.She has been selling kikoi (fabric), door to door for the last ten years to her neighbors, especially women. U. also does farming and sells maize as another source of income. She cites seasonality as her major challenge. During rainy seasons, it becomes difficult for her to move from one house to another.

U. hopes to own a shop and sell in wholesale. In the future she wants to live in rental house with electricity and piped water.She decided to work with Yehu because it is simple to join with no pressuring of clients in terms of payments. She cites electricity as her greatest monthly expense.

loans.use: To purchase Kikoi fabric for resale

loans.name: Iyad

texts.en:
Iyad is a father of three sons and one daughter, lives in Jericho and works occasionally in Israel. Five years ago Iyad started planning for a more sustainable source of income. He started by purchasing two sheep and bred them to have 15 sheep now.

Iyad came to FATEN and took a $3,000 loan to purchase more sheep and expand his farm. Iyad hopes by expanding his business to stop working in Israel and have a stable income to cover life expenses.

Iyad stands next to one of his animals in the photograph above.

loans.use: To buy sheep

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more food for resale

loans.name: Nyamdavaa

texts.en: Nyamdavaa D. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and a child in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His 22 year old son runs a business at Narantuul market while Nyamdavaa and his wife operate a religion items sales business at the same market. They started the business in 1999 by selling valuables and religion items which are sold from their two stalls in the market. Because he has been in business so long, he has gained many business skills, a lot of business knowledge and purchased a plot of land and a house. He says, “Our family wants to improve its living environment by planting greens and plants around the fence”. He is very hard working and open minded person. Nyamdavaa is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan so that he can build a garage and plant more trees and greens.

loans.use: To build a garage

loans.name: Sarantuya

texts.en:
Sarantuya B. is 36 years old and lives with her two children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter attends a local high school. Sarantuya began her business in 2006. She currently operates a sewing business with her two friends in a rented house and they have been madking clothes according to her customers’ specifications. She wants to enlarge her business, not only sewing but it is not easy to operate without sufficient capital. Nevertheless, she operates grocery,growing and selling potatos for domestic consumption. Sarantuya says, “All I want is to grow my business in order to be able to pay my daughter’s tuition who is going to be a student soon and that she can have the best education possible. Also, I am focusing on expanding my sewing business to attract more more customers by making a variety of clothes and other products”. 

Sarantuya is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large amount of fabrics and materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Faith In Action Group

texts.en:
Stanley G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Faith In Action. 

He is 52 years old, married and has five children who range from 7 to 25 years old. He was only able to attend school to 11th grade due to poverty. His children are all attending school. He cares for two siblings. 

For 5 years, he has been involved with crushing and selling crushed rocks in the ELWA Rock Hill community, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 12,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 52,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more rock crushing tools such as shovels, diggers and used tires. He describes himself as a hard-working man.

His dream is to expand his business and to venture into a petroleum business.

loans.use: To buy more rock crushing tools such as shovels, diggers and used tires.

loans.name: Rwamunyari Kwetungura Grp-Ibanda Group

texts.en:
It is now fifteen years since A. Charles started his farming business in Rwamunyari Cell, Ibanda, in Western Uganda. With this as his only means of livelihood, he has managed to make ends meet although with some long seasonal income fluctuations and high labor-cost challenges.

With hard work, this married and happy-go-lucky father of two children has kept his business growing. In a week, he makes 30,000 Ugandan shillings out of selling mostly bananas. His business plan of action for the future is to be able to sell more bananas out of his farm to an increasingly expanding market.

With this loan, Charles plans to purchase manure and fertilizer for his plantation. 

Charles is the man standing on the right in the front row raising his hand. The rest of the ladies with their hands raised belong to the group committee.

loans.use: To purchase high value manure and fertilizers for his plantation so that it can regain its fertility

loans.name: Tsendsuren

texts.en:
Tsendsuren D., 61, lives with her husband in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent home, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband, Yadamsuren, owns a car and earns money by transporting people. Tsendsuren operates a grocery trading business at Narantuul, the biggest market in Ulaanbaatar. She started her grocery service in 2000, quickly making good progress and gaining valuable experience.

A very hardworking, open-minded and responsible woman focused on operating an honest business, she is now requesting a 2,900,000 MNT loan to purchase a car for her youngest son. Tsendsuren says, "I will work hard to pay the bank loan on time. The earnings from grocery sales will enable us to pay the loan on time."

loans.use: To purchase a car

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
Rosana M., 41, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Jesus M., a welder, and they are blessed with six children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She is engaged in sewing together recycled scraps of cloth into cleaning rags which are used for household and industrial purposes

Rosana has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her rug-making business.

To ensure the success of her business, Rosana would like to apply for a PHP 20,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying equipment and raw materials needed to continue production of cleaning rags for sale.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can buy her own delivery vehicle.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment and raw materials needed to continue production of cleaning rags for sale

loans.name: Zorigoo

texts.en:
Zorigoo B. is 23 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. His wife is unemployed while his daughter is at home.

Zorigoo makes furniture in his own fenced yard near the family home. He started this business in 2009 and has since made quality furnishings for the people of his province. He wants to one day rent a small carpentry workshop and operate the business with his brother. He also wants to expand his business by building a workplace to sell more furniture and further improve his family’s financial situation and their quality of life.

Zorigoo is very modest person. He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to buy more wood and furniture-making supplies for his business.

loans.use: To buy more wood and furniture-making supplies for his business

loans.name: Tailoring Group

texts.en: Korbo B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Tailoring." She is 28 years old, married and has two children 3 and 5 years old. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. For 3 years, she has been sewing and selling garments and school uniforms in the ELWA community outside Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more cloth to sew more garments and school uniforms. She describes herself as easy going. Her goal is to improve her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more cloth to sew more garments and school uniforms.

loans.name: Mustafa

texts.en:
Mustafa is a student at Al-Quds Open University. He lives in Bethlehem and works while studying so he can afford to pay his tuition fees and contribute to his family's household expenses. 

Mustafa saved a good amount of money and then took a $3,000 loan from FATEN to start a small restaurant near the students residences. The area is in need of a restaurant, because the closest restaurant is 30 minutes away. Mustafa will use the loan to purchase needed cooking tools and machines. With the profit from his restaurant, he can pay his tuition fees and other expenses and help his parents pay for their household expenses.

In the photograph, Mustafa appears in front of the FATEN office.

loans.use: Restaurant equipment and supplies

loans.name: Nerisa

texts.en:
Nerisa O., 46, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Ulysses O., a community councilman, and they are blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Nerisa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.

To ensure the success of her business, Nerisa would like to apply for a PHP 50,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying groceries, toiletries and beverages needed to replenish and maintain her current inventory.

Nerisa dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a good and comfortable life for herself and her children.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries, toiletries and beverages needed to replenish and maintain her current inventory

loans.name: Munhjav

texts.en:
Munhjav G. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Hovd province, western Mongolia. The family lives in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent.

Munhjav currently operates a clothing trade business in her town to support her family. She started her business in 2009 and since then it has become stable. Her husband runs a transportation service throughout the province.

Munhjav has found success in her new trade and attributes this to her good business knowledge and selling skills. She is very hardworking and optimistic and is very persistent in achieving her goals. She says, "My business is continuing quite well. I run it with my friends, but I want to purchase a container where I will sell the products and work separately and independently from my friends someday."

Munhjav is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase and import more clothes for her business from Erlian, a city of China. Munhjav is in the middle of the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: K. Hasan is a 47-year-old married man who owns a small farm. He is a hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children, who today are working adults thanks to his example. Hasan runs a business raising and selling cattle and has ten years of experience in this field. Since cattle raising and selling is a profitable business, he has become a very successful businessman in a very short period. He works very hard and spends all his time with his animals cleaning, feeding and pasturing them. Now, Hasan wants to expand his business and buy more cattle, so he applied for a loan of 12,000 Somoni. He thanks all lenders for their support. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchasing more cattle in order to expand his business

loans.name: Beyan Group

texts.en: Samuel B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "B. Group." He is 42 years old, single and has one child who is 6 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty. For 11 years, he has been selling cosmetics such as creme, powder, and hair grease at the Old Road Market, outside Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 14,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 58,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more cosmetics such as creme, powder, and hair grease. He describes himself as a trust-worthy person. His dream is to expand his business and build a shop.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics such as creme, powder, and hair grease.

loans.name: Shohnazar

texts.en:
S. Shohnazar, a 34-year-old married father of two children, has been selling household goods such as kettles, pails, basins and many other items for the past seven years in order to support his family. The business is quite successful, carrying goods that meet client demand, thereby generating a stable income that allows Shohnazar to improve the living conditions of his family and make his children happy. A recipient of two previous loans from IMON, he is now requesting $3000 USD to enlarge the range of goods he carries. Be an important part of the growth of Shohnazar’s business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new household goods to enlarge his range of goods.

loans.name: Adel

texts.en:
Adel is a 48-year-old married man living in Lebanon. When he was young, he started learning the hairdressing occupation as a new career in his life; he first learned it in an academy. Then he started becoming a talented hairdresser and in 1995, he opened his own hairdressing salon and started working on his own. 

Since then, his salon has improved, and Adel has been offering more services to his clients such as beauty products, nail care, makeup, and more. He receives clients from his village; he says that his clients can be his friends, neighbors and also tourists. 

Today, Adel is asking for a loan to buy beauty products and additional supplies, such as hair gels, shaving soap, etc. He hopes that the result of this will increase his business productivity, as well as his income.

loans.use: to buy beauty products and supplies

loans.name: Nimer

texts.en:
Nimer is a 32 year old married Lebanese entrepreneur. In 1975, Nimer’s father opened his grocery store. He used to help his father after school, on weekends, and on holidays. Therefore, in 2000, he took after his father and decided to operate and manage his father’s grocery store in his town. Nimer has good experience in trading and he is is very well known in his region since the shop has been open for 35 years now. His family has always supported him in developing and improving his work. He offers food products, dairy products, breads, cereals, drinks, canned food, bread, candies, and more products to his clients. 

Today, Nimer is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise to stock his shop in the hopes that this will increase his sales and, therefore, his income.

loans.use: for store inventory

loans.name: Mukaram

texts.en:
A. Mukaram is 53 years old. She is divorced and has one child. For many years she tried various types of the activities. Finally, three years ago together with her son she started a business selling cell phones. Mukaram believes that this business is profitable and the generated income allows her to support her family. 

However, Mukaram thinks that it is expensive to purchase the cell phones locally and it will save funds considerably to purchase the goods in China. For this purpose Mukaram requests 5,100 Somoni. Being a first time borrower, Mukaram is grateful to all supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy cell phones from China for resale

loans.name: Ahmadshekh

texts.en:
A. Ahmadshekh is a 34-year-old married man who lives with his wife and three children. Ahmadshekh works as an inspector of a government agency of social insurance and pensions. Since he earns little he also runs a business raising and selling cattle. He has 12 years of experience in this field. 

Since cattle raising and selling is a profitable business, Ahmadshekh has become a very successful businessman. Ahmadshekh has a friendly family who always try to help each other. He works very hard and spends his weekend time with the cattle, cleaning, feeding and pasturing them. Now Ahmadshekh wants to expand his business and buy more cattle. So for that he applied for a loan of 7,000 Somoni. With your help Ahmadshekh can get ahead.

loans.use: to expand cattle holdings

loans.name: Bahodir

texts.en:
K. Bahodir is 38, married, and has three children. Bahodir's goals are to grow in his personal life and in his business. His wish is to offer better service to his customers. His dream is that God continues to provide him with more life to get ahead and to fulfill his goals. 

He is a taxi driver and travels the streets of Spitamen city in search of customers. He has owned his business for 5 years. At the same time together with the help of his family he runs a grocery sales business. Currently Bahodir’s car needs thorough repair and he wants to borrow 5,000 Somoni. The financing will go towards general repairs of his vehicle, the purchase of additional foodstuffs for his grocery store, and to buy an additional deep-freezer for expanding his business. He thanks Kiva and all lenders that make this help possible.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

loans.use: repair of a taxi, grocery store inventory, and deep-freezer

loans.name: Egamberdi

texts.en:
K. Egamberdi has made a living raising cattle and grinding grain in his mill for the last 12 years and has vast experience in this field. He is married and the father of four children. He enjoys his work, and is happy because it allows him to feed his family and care for his home. He would like to buy more cattle to raise, and has applied for a loan for $2,000 to make this possible. He is extremely grateful for your generous heart.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: To expand a cattle-raising business

loans.name: Hakimjon

texts.en:
Hakimjon is a responsible father and a loving son. Since he was very young, he has made a living doing the honorable work of raising livestock, work which he learned from his parents and which gives him great satisfaction. Thanks to his skill and hard work, his business is doing well and he would like to expand it by buying more cattle to raise, and more feed for them to eat. Hakimjon believes this will allow him to expand his business and earn a higher price for his livestock.

loans.use: To expand his cattle-raising business

loans.name: Mawoulé

texts.en: Mawoulé D. makes a living selling automobile parts in the town of Lomé. He is married to a merchant and they have two children. His business is doing well because when cars crash or break down, he is able to buy them and scavenge their still-usable parts for resale from his shop. It’s a good business to be in, and he’d like to expand by securing this loan to buy more more cars and parts.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for resale

loans.name: Gani

texts.en:
R. Gani is a young man who likes to make his own way. He supports his family, which includes his wife, one child and his parents, by selling clothes. Little by little, thanks mostly to his commitment to hard work, his business has expanded. Gani wants to continue this growth, and to make that possible has applied for a loan of $3,000. He will use this money to buy more clothing to sell to his customers. With your help, Gani will be able to save money, expand his business and improve his family's life.     

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell to his customers

loans.name: Yesu Nhyira Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Margaret describes herself as a smart woman. She is married to a farmer and together they have six children. She is now forty-five years old. 

Margaret lives together with her family at Berekum, where she also has her business. She is able to provide support for her family’s financial needs through the sale of 'kenkey'. 'Kenkey' is a Ghanaian favorite dish that is rich in carbohydrate. It is prepared with corn dough made into balls, cooked between 1-2 hours and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish. It could also be enjoyed with other sauces. 'Kenkey' is known throughout all the tribes in Ghana and commonly sold on most streets. Margaret has sold 'kenkey' for 10 years. 

Margaret is currently the leader of a trust bank group called “Yesu Nhyira”, (which means "Jesus’ Blessings"), made up of five members. Her dreams include expanding her business and ensuring that her children become hard-working individuals to help society.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed A. makes a living working as an embroiderer and tailor. He started this business in 2007 to generate income for himself and his wife. He is requesting his first loan from WAGES of 400,000 CFA. With this loan, he plans to buy an embroidery machine that he can use to make more intricate designs and improve his products. This will attract new customers and increase his ability to provide good service to his current ones.

loans.use: To buy an embroidery machine

loans.name: Shepherd Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Friendly Emelia is a widow and the mother of two children between 6 and 12 years old. She is now 35 years old. She lives together with her children in a community near Berekum, where she also has her business. She is able to support herself and her children through food-selling. She operates a food stall and sells “fufu” and “banku”. 

Banku and fufu are very popular local dishes among the Akan communities in Ghana, prepared from cassava with plantains and maize respectively. Selling for the past 10 years, Emelia has made quite a number of repeat customers through good customer relations. She plans to invest the loan to purchase cassava, plantains, maize, fish, meat and other food ingredients in bulk to improve her food quality.

Emelia is currently the leader of a trust bank group called 'Shepherd', made up of five members. Her dreams include ensuring healthy living for her children and extending help to other family members.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients in bulk.

loans.name: Afiwa

texts.en:
Afiwa A. sells diapers, children’s clothing, and other baby products. She is 39 years old and married to a teacher. They have three children.

Afiwa has been in this particular business selling baby items since 2009. She has requested her first loan from WAGES of 350,000 CFA. She plans to use half to purchase diapers and the other half to purchase children’s outfits.

loans.use: To purchase diapers and children's outfits

loans.name: Jesus Power Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Used clothes are mostly patronized in Ghana because brand-new ones are expensive for the majority of low income people. Therefore, selling used clothes has created a market for women like Comfort. 

Comfort is currently the group leader of 'Jesus Power' Trust bank Group, made up of 5 members. Comfort is clearly a humble woman. She is 42 years old and sells used clothes to customers in her community. Comfort has been operating her businesses for 15 years and she is eager to be taking out this loan. She plans to invest the loan to purchase bales of assorted used clothes to serve her customers. 


Comfort is married to a carpenter and together they have five children from age 10 – 21 years. Comfort’s dreams include owning a house and providing quality education for her children.

loans.use: To purchase used clothes in bales

loans.name: Kokowi

texts.en:
Kokowi A. owns a restaurant in Lomé where he makes spaghetti, rice dishes, and other popular Togolese meals. The restaurant has been open since 2006, though this is his first micro-loan from WAGES.

Kokowi is married to another merchant and they have three children. He has requested this loan of 300,000 CFA that he plans to use to purchase milk, couscous, spaghetti, sugar, and other staples of his restaurant’s menu.

loans.use: To purchase food for his restaurant

loans.name: Seham

texts.en:
Seham S. is the mother of four daughters and one son. She is married to a construction worker and the family lives in Bethlehem. Seham's husband doesn't have stable employment, so it is hard to take care of a family.

In an attempt to help her husband Seham, sold all of her gold accessories to get the money to start a small grocery store. Recently, Seham wanted to expand the store and purchase more goods in order to increase her profits and attract a larger number of customers.

In the photo, Seham appears in the store with her son.

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Nagimatou

texts.en:
Madame Nagimatou I. sells firewood and charcoal from her home. This is a small but lucrative business that she has had for about four years.

Madame I. has experience taking micro-loans from WAGES and has requested her third loan of 400,000 CFA. She plans to use the loan to purchase more firewood and charcoal to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and firewood to sell

loans.name: Awurade Mo Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Susana describes herself as faithful. She is 28 years old and she is the leader of the “Awurade mo” (translated as 'thank you Lord') borrower group. Susana lives in a town near Berekum and sells smoked fish in the community market. She has been running her fish business for 6 years. She is excited to be taking out this loan, which she will use to purchase baskets of smoked fish. 

Susana is married to a mason and together they have three children ages 2, 4, and 9 years old. She dreams of becoming a fish wholesaler and hopes to sell enough fish to be able to provide better education for her children. As the leader of the borrower group, Susana ensures that all members attend meetings and submit their repayments.

loans.use: To purchase baskets of smoked fish

loans.name: Issa Aminou

texts.en:
Mr. Issa Aminou A. and his brother have a large general store in Lomé, Togo, where they sell lots of groceries, food, and other products. Stores like Issa’s are very lucrative – people like the convenience they offer as a kind of “one-stop shop”.

The brothers have had the store since 2005. Issa has requested his first loan of 300,000 CFA in order to purchase more merchandise to sell in his store and to generally expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for his store

loans.name: Faith And Work Group

texts.en: Alfred M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Faith And Work." He is 38, married and has one child a year and 4 months old. He also cares for one sibling. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of financial support. For 5 years, he has been involved with transportation and the sale of crushed rock in the Thinkers Village community, outside Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy petroleum and other materials like diggers, shovels and old tires used in the production of crushed rock. He describes himself as an easy-going man whose dream is to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy more petroleum and other materials like diggers, shovels and used tires used in the production of crushed rock.

loans.name: Dédé

texts.en:
Mrs. Dédé d’Almeida is 57 years old and is married with three children. Her husband is a retired accountant, so it is up to her to provide her family’s income. To do so Madame d’Almeida sells charcoal and firewood out of her home in Lomé, Togo.

Mrs. d’Almeida has requested her first loan from WAGES of 150,000 CFA. She plans to use the loan to purchase more charcoal and firewood to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and firewood to sell

loans.name: Truth Borrower Group

texts.en:
Juliana is forty-one years old. She is married and she is the mother of three children from age 2-8 years. Juliana is a hard-working trader. She sells smoked fish. 

Fish is widely used in cooking as one the most common sources of protein in our diet. It is mostly used in the preparation of soup and sauces. Fresh fish is partially roasted on a fire to obtain smoked fish which is more flavorful. 

Juliana plans to use the loan to purchase cartons of fresh fish in bulk from wholesalers to scale up her business. She has been in business for two years and hopes to expand her business to meet customers’ demand. She dreams of owning a shed in the community market and also aspires to see her children reach higher levels in education. 

Juliana is the leader of a trust bank group called 'Truth'. There are seven members in this group who are mostly farmers. The group has adopted the co-guarantee system to obtain the loan and uses peer pressure and assistance to one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase cartons of fish

loans.name: Rukhsana Begum's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana begum lives in Multan, the city of tombs and saints’ places in Pakistan.

Rukhsana sells clothes which helps her to fulfill the basic needs of her family. Her husband sells vegetables on a four-wheeled cart. He puts the vegetables on his cart in the morning and goes to different areas of the community to sell and make an income.

They both are very hardworking persons and do their work with effort and dedication. They have good working experience in their businesses.

Rukhsana begum has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to buy seasonal vegetables to sell. He will buy a greater variety of vegetables to put on his cart. Rukhsana is hopeful that this will increase her husband’s chances to make more income.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal vegetables for her husband's business

loans.name: Praise Group

texts.en:
Martha N., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Praise. She is 51 years old, married and has three children who range from 29 to 35 years old.

She was only able to attend school through 8th grade due to a lack of financial support. 

For 5 years, she has been selling oil, rice and charcoal in Thinkers Village community, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more oil, rice and charcoal. 

She describes herself as easy going. Her goal is to improve her business and travel aboard to do business.

loans.use: To buy more oil, rice and charcoal.

loans.name: Albert

texts.fr:
N. Albert est née dans le capital du BURUNDI (Bujumbura) dans un district de Kibitoki, il était  au Burundi comme refugié Rwandais, il est rentré dans son pays d'origine en 1995 après le génocide perpétré contre les Tutsi de 1994 .Il est célibataire, âgée de 28 ans, son niveau d’étude est six ans de primaire (6ans).

Il exerce son business dans le centre ville de NYAMATA, comme commerçant de détail en boutique, sa résidence est un peu rurale, il exerce les activités d’agriculture (il cultive les sorghos, haricots et maniocs) pouvant lui aider dans la vie quotidienne de sa famille.

C’est son premier  prêt contracté auprès d’ACB et avec ce prêt, il a acheté  des articles pour ravitailler son business avec lequel il compte devenir riche. Pour acheter la farine de maïs, du sucre , des savons, boissons limonades (Fanta) pour augmenter son chiffre d’affaires et continuer a aller de l’avant surtout économiquement. Comme il le dit, ses ambitions sont de mieux rembourser son prêt pour que la Banque lui accorde un prêt d’un gros montant pour acheter les articles important, afin d’agrandir les profits de ses activités ainsi devenir un grand commerçant.

Dans l’avenir, il compte à améliorer ses activités en augmentant la quantité de ces produits et améliorer ses conditions de vie. A part ça, il compte se marier et avoir des enfants et un bon foyer dans le futur pour reconstruire son pays.
texts.en:
N. Albert was born in the capital of BURUNDI (Bujumbura) in the district of Kibitoki. He was in Burundi as a Rwandan refugee, and he returned to his country of origin in 1995, after the genocide perpetrated against the Tutsi in 1994. He is 28, single, and managed to finish 6 years of primary school. He does business in the center of the town of NYAMATA, as a retailer with a little shop. His home is somewhat rural, so he also plants sorghum, beans, and manioc for his family's day-to-day consumption. This is his first loan with ACB, and he used it to buy inventory for his business, with which he hopes to become rich. This loan of 500,000 Rwandan francs served to buy maize flour, sugar, soap, and sodas (Fanta) so that he can increase his turnover and continue to make progress, especially economically speaking. He says that his ambition is to reimburse his loan well so that the Bank will accord him a larger amount and he can buy a lot of items so as to increase the profit from his business and become a wholesaler. In the future he intends to improve his business by buying more products and improve his living conditions. Apart from that, he intends to have a wife and children and a good household later on so as to reconstruct his country.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of soap, maize flour, and beans to stock his shop better

loans.name: Costa Alegre Group

texts.es:
Las mencionadas mujeres son de la Compañía Cabañas (Costa Alegre) de la Ciudad de Caacupe. 
Son Señoras, que trabajan en su mayoría en la producción  y venta de plantas en sus propios hogares, se dedican al cultivo y venta de plantas a gran escala. 
 Una de ellas es la señora Florentina,  quien sale de madrugada de su hogar  y viaja con sus plantas para comercializarlos en distintos puntos del país, la gran mayoría viaja en condiciones precarias   por falta de vehículos propios.
Gracias a la ayuda de su familia en esta actividad cubren todos los gasto de la familia, y solicita el préstamo para la compra de semillas, bolsas para macetas y abonas, todo para una mejor y mayor producción de plantas.
texts.en:
The women mentioned in this description are from the Cabañas (Costa Alegre) Group in the city of Caacupe. Most of these ladies grow plants on a large scale and sell them from their homes.

One of these women is Sra. Florentina. She sells plants out of her home beginning at dawn and also travels to different parts of the country to sell them. Many people like her travel in difficult conditions since they lack their own vehicles.

Thanks to the help of her family, her business is able to cover all of the family expenses. Florentina is requesting a loan to buy seeds, flowerpots, and sacks of compost so that she can improve and increase her plant production.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds, flowerpots, and sacks of compost

loans.name: We Are One Group

texts.en:
Mamie K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called “We Are One”. She is 32 years old, is single, and has three children who range from 3 to 16 years old. She was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to financial constraints. All of her children are attending school.

For more than six years, Mamie has been selling rice, oil, onions, tomatoes and beans at Old Road Joe Bar Market, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

Mamie plans to use her 8,500 Liberian dollar portion of this 43,500 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bags of rice, oil, onions, tomatoes and beans. She describes herself as a strong businesswoman.

Mamie’s dream is to improve her business, build a house, and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Adam is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, oil, onions, tomatoes and beans

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran is very supportive of her family. She has a boutique where she sells her handmade clothes and does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. She takes orders from different shops in Multan and supplies them on-time to make an income. She has been in doing this work for over six years.

Sughran uses a room of her house as a boutique to display her work to her customers. She does this because the rent of shops is too high in Multan. Her customer base is purely women. She prepares women’s wear such as shalwar kamiz and kurtas (pant and tunic outfits), etc. These two items are specifically used in Pakistan because this is its culture and women like to wear them.

Sughran has applied for a loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). With the loan she will be able to buy material such as clothes, beads and thread in bulk to fulfill larger orders for her customers. She is hopeful that she can earn a good profit and improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase required materials for her boutique

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is a dairy farmer in Nyamira town in Western Kenya. She is 46 years old and married with five children between the ages of 14 and 27. Two of her children are still attending school.

Norah has been practicing mixed farming for twenty-one years with only one employee. Her main products are milk and tea which she sells to the local market. She is also running a business in the same area. Her biggest challenges in farming are animal diseases which affect her dairy cows.

Norah has requested this Kes 45,000 loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve her family's living standard.

In future, Norah would like to purchase more dairy cows to increase her productivity. She is happy with the services rendered and would like to continue being a member.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Vicente

texts.es:
