At present she runs her business with the help of her children. Her husband works at a teachers' institute, and they both support the home. Delfina has been with FINCA Perú for around eighteen years. Thanks to the loans she has received she was able to open her business and continue to grow her sales. With her savings she has been able to build her house out of good materials. Her dream is to complete the second floor. She's seeking a loan for 2600 soles to buy rice and sacks of sugar wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice and sacks of sugar

loans.name: Malinche Group

texts.es:
El grupo el Malince lo conforman tres mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es la señora Rosa Amanda Montiel  quien tiene una pequeña venta donde comercializa granos básicos, café, gaseosas, frescos, helados y chiverías. Ella con el préstamo comprar los productos para su venta por ejemplo la gaseosa cada tres días hace se facturan.

Asimismo esta señora de 55 años quien tiene nueve hijos de los cuales tres son menores de edad sueña con componer su casa especialmente tener un espacio adecuado para el negocio y que no se encuentre en la sala de su hogar sino en una caseta aparte por lo menos este año tratara de hacer el arranque. 

Sus compañeras de grupo son Rosalina de Jesús  R. Vázquez se dedica a la venta de hisopa lo cual se utiliza para caliar las cunetas y María Virginia Joaquín Martín quien vende ropa y cosméticos.
texts.en:
The Malinche group is made up of three women workers. One of them, Rosa Amanda, has a small store where she sells basic grains, coffee, soft drinks, ice cream and Chivería products [yogurt, milk etc]. She plans to use the loan to buy merchandise for her store. She is billed every three days for the soft drinks. Rosa is 55 years old. She has nine kids, three of which are minors. She dreams of being able to make improvements in her home. Specifically, she would like to have adequate space for her business; preferably, not attached to a room of her home but rather,n in a separate structure. She hopes to open shop at least by the end of the year. Her group partners are Rosalina de Jesús and María Virgina. Rosalina works selling paintbrushes which are used for whitewashing roadside drainage channels and María sells clothing and cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Tyson Shelley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase basic grains, soft drinks, dairy products etc.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia es socia del Bancomunal Paloma, es conviviente tiene 2 hijos de 13 y 10 años, ambos estan estudiando actualmente. Antonia tiene una tienda de productos variados en su casa, desde pequeña le gustaron los negocios, antes vendía golosinas en un puesto en el Hospital, ahora el negocio lo maneja en casa, asi esta mas pendiente de sus hijos, ellos le ayudan en el negocio los fines de semana.

Antonia tiene 3 años aproximadamente en FINCA Peru, las capacitaciones le han ayudado sobre todo en los temas de cómo atender a los clientes.

Antonia solicita un préstamo de 1200 soles para la compra de abarrotes como arroz, azúcar al por mayor, cada saco que compra el dura 1 semana en su negocio, es por ello que aprovechará con el préstamo en comprar sacos para varios meses.

El sueño de Antonia es tener un negocio mas grande en su casa, como un bar, y construir su casa de material noble.
texts.en:
Antonia is a member of the Paloma (The Dove) communal bank; she has two children, 13 and 10 years old, who are students. Antonia has a grocery store in her home. She’s liked business since she was a little girl; she used to sell sweets at a stand in a hospital but now runs her business from home so that she can watch over her children better. They help out with the store on weekends. Antonia has collaborated with FINCA Perú for about three years; the training sessions have been very helpful for her especially with regards to customer service. Antonia is asking for a 1200 sol loan to buy grocery items like rice and sugar at wholesale. Each sack she buys lasts a week in her store so she will take advantage of the loan to buy several sacks in order to have stock available for several months. Antonia’s dream is to have a larger business, like a bar, in her home and to build her house out of substantial building materials.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grocery items at wholesale.

loans.name: Donata

texts.es:
Donata es socia del Bancomunal Paloma, es conviviente, tiene 3 hijos que están estudiando en la escuela, el mayor de 17 años termina el colegio este año y desea prepararse para sus estudios superiores.
Donata tiene un negocio de venta de comida, esta actividad la realiza 3 veces a la semana en las ferias, los otros días aprovecha en la compra de ganado para su posterior venta de carne. Donata ha trabajado desde muy joven, ha vendido ropa, antiguamente canjeaba productos por carne, también ha trabajado de ambulante y en una empresa pesquera.
Donata solicita un préstamo de 2000 soles, dinero que utilizará en la compra de víveres al por mayor para la preparación de comidas, como son: arroz, azúcar, aceite. Los sueños de Donata es tener una tienda de abarrotes grande o un restaurante, para ello esta buscando un lugar para alquilar.
texts.en:
Donata is a member of the Paloma (The Dove) communal bank. She lives with her life partner and has three children who are in school; the oldest is 17 years old and will be finishing high school this year and wants to prepare for his university studies. Donata sells prepared food three times a week at various farmers markets. The other days she buys cattle for subsequent meat sales. Donata has worked since she was very young; she has sold clothing and used to trade items for meat, she’s also worked as a peddler and has been employed by a fish processing plant. Donata is asking for 2000 soles to buy wholesale food items like rice, sugar and cooking oil to use in her meal preparations. Donata dreams with having a large grocery store or a restaurant and is looking for a place to rent suitable for this purpose.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs at wholesale.

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena es socia del Bancomunal Paloma, es casada y tiene 5 hijos, el mayor de 17 años y la menor de 6 años. Elena se inició en el negocio con la ayuda de su esposo, pusieron una tiendita en su casa, su esposo es artesano y junto a sus hijos le ayuda en las ventas, Elena también trabaja como Asistenta en el Hospital de Huamanga.

Elena solicita un préstamo de 1800 soles, dinero que sera invertido en la compra de arroz, harina en sacos al por mayor para su negocio, agradece a FINCA por los prestamos recibidos, pues no solo han sido un apoyo económico, sino que gracias a las capacitaciones a aprendido a como invertir.

El sueño de Elena es tener una tienda mayorista en su casa, ella vive junto al terminal terrestre y piensa que puede ser un gran negocio aprovechando al publico que frecuenta el terminal.
texts.en:
Elena is a member of the Paloma (The Dove) comunal bank; she is married and has 5 children who range in ages from 17 to 6 years. Elena started out in her business with help from her husband; they set up a small store in their home. Her husband is an artisan and together with their children he helps her with sales. Elena also works as an assistant in Huamanga’s hospital. Elena is asking for an 1800 sol loan to buy sacks of rice and flour at wholesale for her store. She is grateful to FINCA for the loans received because they haven’t been just an economic help but thanks to the training sessions she has learned how to invest. Elena’s dream is to have a wholesale store in her home. She lives next to the land transportation terminal and she feels that this would be a great business because of the large number of people who frequent the terminal.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sacks of rice and flour at wholesele.

loans.name: Sarai Group

texts.es:
El grupo Sarai está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es María José G. M. quien vende gaseosas y bisutería desde hace cinco años. Ella tiene tres hijos el menor tiene 2 años y los mayores tienen 11 y 15 años de edad quienes estudian y le ayudan a ver el negocio.

Sus compañeras de grupo son María Incilla E. S. Martínez quien tiene una pequeña pulpería y Melba del Socorro Baltodano quien vende frescos y helados. Ellas invertirán el crédito en sus negocios con el propósito de prosperar.
texts.en:
The Saraj group is made up of three hard working women. One of them is María José G. M. who has sold sodas and costume jewelry for the last five years. She has three children, the smallest is 2 years old and the older ones are 11 and 15 years old, in school and help with her business. Her partners in the group are María Incilla E. S. Martínez, who has a small convenience store, and Melba del Socorro Baltodano, who sells fruit drinks and ice cream. They will invest the proceeds of the loan in their businesses with the goal of prospering.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of costume jewelry and soda beverages.

loans.name: Laura Yesenia

texts.es:
Laura tiene 34 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a sus padres en el distrito de Nueva Arica, una zona dedicada principalmente a actividades agrícolas como la ganadería y el cultivo de tabaco, se encuentra ubicada a una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace tres años a la venta de productos de primera necesidad y abarrotes en una bodega instalada en su domicilio, ella adquiere sus productos en la ciudad de Chiclayo y en Cayaltí, Laura trata de ofrecer productos de calidad y brindar un trato amable, gracias a estas acciones se ha hecho conocida en el medio y actualmente cuenta con un grupo de clientes que prefieren comprar en su negocio.

Laura desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más mercadería de modo que pueda incrementar sus ventas y percibir mas ganancias, por ello ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que le permitan alcanzar su objetivo.

Laura es una mujer trabajadora y que siempre se esfuerza para ayudar a sus padres a salir adelante. En la zona donde vive sus vecinos y conocidos le consideran una persona tranquila y honrada.
texts.en:
Laura, 34, is single and lives with her parents in Nueva Arica district, a mostly agricultural area where the main activities are cattle-raising and tobacco growing; it’s located an hour and a half away from the city of Chiclayo. For the last three years she has run a grocery store located in her home. She acquires her stock in Chiclayo and Cayaltí; she tries to offer high-quality products and provide pleasant customer service. Thanks to this, she has become well-known in the area and currently has a group of regular customer s that prefers to buy in her store. Laura wants to expand her business buying more merchandise so that her sales will increase and thus her profits will too. She has asked Edpyme Alternativa, therefore, for a 2000 new sol loan that will help her reach this goal. Laura is a hard-working woman who always strives to help her parents get ahead. In the area where she lives her neighbors and acquaintances consider her to be a level headed and honest person.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

loans.name: Nicolas De Los Santos

texts.es:
Nicolas de los Santos L. es una persona trabajadora, esforzada, emprendedora, humilde y con muchos deseos de auto superación. El se dedica al comercio de plata con la compra y venta de dicho producto actividad que realiza desde hace 15 años y que espera que prospere.

L. es casado y tiene cuatro hijos de 12, 10, 5 años y un bebe de 2 meses  y su mayor sueño y meta es poder brindarles estudios a sus hijos primordialmente y una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Nicolas de los Santos L. is a hard-working, dedicated, enterprising, unassuming person who very much wants to get ahead in life. He has been a silver merchant for 15 years and hopes to prosper. He is married and has four children who's ages are 12, 10 and 5 years and a two-month-old baby. His greatest wish and goal is to provide his children with a good education and a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For silver.

loans.name: Apao

texts.en:
Apao I. is from the village of Panduma, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 42 years old, married, and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Apao owns and operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Apao has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Apao joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Apao is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac H. T. is a 19-year-old pepper producer who lives in the region of Coquital de Los Chiles de San Carlos, located in Northern Costa Rica. Isaac is a dedicated producer. He plans to focus his efforts on the planting and harvest of Cayenne peppers. He works in cooperation with his family to strike a balance between accomplishing the daily tasks associated with agricultural production and the completion of domestic responsibilities. In general, the work day is divided into mornings and afternoons. In the morning, the domestic tasks are carried out such as cooking, cleaning and taking care of younger siblings. Afternoons are generally dedicated to harvest and planting – working the land as needed. The land they work is their own.

 In addition to his agricultural activity, Isaac spends some days working as a labourer in the nearby orange producing factory in order to supplement the family income, but this work is sporadic. The money he earns helps pay bills for electricity and buys food. The rural zone where Isaac and his family live is one of the few places in Costa Rica without running water; the family must pump water from a nearby well as needed. Isaac is working hard for the sustenance of his family, striving to reap the maximum benefits from his land and his labour. 

Although this is an individual loan, the community in which Isaac and his family live is very close-knit and interdependent. Neighbours help and support one another by sharing experiences and expertise acquired over the years. All individual members of the Coquital community are dedicated to the improvement of living conditions for the region as a whole. This loan will be used to finance the production of Cayenne peppers. Specifically, the loan will be used to finance the purchase of a variety of seedlings and necessary agricultural nutrients, fertilizers and chemicals in order to ensure a healthy harvest. All labour and logistical tasks associated with production will be carried out by Isaac with the help of his family members in the region of Coquital de Los Chiles, located in the Northern Region of Costa Rica. Isaac will need roughly one year before his peppers will reach maturity and be ready for harvest. 

The main factor that has stood in the way of increasing his production levels has been the Costa Rican government and various other institutions. Formal banks, lending agencies and government bodies have failed to recognize the producers of the Coquital region as legitimate producers, worthy of financial and governmental support and services. 

Piper and Capiscum Processors Compañía Agrícola Industrial, or PROPICA, is an international buyer and seller of chili pepper and ground pepper products. In cooperation with Fundación Mujer, PROPICA has guaranteed to purchase the agricultural products (the peppers) that are to be produced with the help of this loan. PROPICA acts as a guaranteed client for small agricultural producers in the area of Coquital, thus ensuring that their products will reach market. 

The collaboration of Fundación Mujer and PROPICA represents a unique opportunity for Isaac, his family and community. By offering a source of start-up capital and a guaranteed client to purchase what is produced, there is a chance to improve family and community standards of living. Above all, Isaac wants to take advantage of the current opportunity that has been presented; he wants to profit from this collaboration and see improvements in his neighbourhood.

loans.use: For the purchase of seeds and nutrients necessary for the production of peppers

loans.name: Lumbi

Lumbi is a dedicated producer and father. He plans to focus his efforts on the planting and harvest of Cayenne peppers. He works in cooperation with his family to strike a balance between accomplishing the daily tasks associated with agricultural production and the completion of domestic responsibilities. In general, the work day is divided into mornings and afternoons. In the morning, the domestic tasks are carried out such as cooking, cleaning and sending the children to school. Afternoons are generally dedicated to harvest and planting – working the land as needed. The land they work is their own. 

In addition to his agricultural activity, Lumbi spends some days working as a labourer in the nearby orange producing factory in order to supplement family income, but this work is sporadic. The money he earns helps pay bills for electricity and buys food. The rural zone where Lumbi and his family live is one of the few places in Costa Rica without running water; the family must pump water from a nearby well as needed. Lumbi is working hard towards the sustenance of his family, striving to reap the maximum benefits from his land and his labour. 

Although this is an individual loan, the community in which Lumbi and his family live is very close-knit and interdependent. Neighbours help and support one another by sharing experiences and expertise acquired over the years. All individual members of the Medio Queso community are dedicated to the improvement of living conditions for the region as a whole.

This loan will be used to finance the production of Cayenne peppers. Specifically, the loan will be used to finance the purchase of a variety of seedlings and necessary agricultural nutrients, fertilizers and chemicals in order to ensure a healthy harvest. All labour and logistical tasks associated with production will be carried out by Lumbi with the help of his family members in the region of Medio Queso de Los Chiles, located in the Northern Region of Costa Rica. Lumbi will need roughly one year before his peppers will reach maturity and be ready for harvest. In the past, it has been difficult for Lumbi to access financial services and technical advice regarding farming practices. This has been a factor that has hindered his ability to be as productive as possible. 

Piper and Capiscum Processors Compañía Agrícola Industrial, or PROPICA, is an international buyer and seller of chili pepper and ground pepper products. In cooperation with Fundación Mujer, PROPICA has guaranteed to purchase the agricultural products (the peppers) that are to be produced with the help of this loan. PROPICA acts as a guaranteed client for small agricultural producers in the area of Medio Queso, thus ensuring that their products will reach market. 

The collaboration of Fundación Mujer and PROPICA represents a unique opportunity for Lumbi, his family and community. By offering a source of start-up capital and a guaranteed client to purchase what is produced, there is a chance to improve family and community standards of living. Above all, Lumbi wants to take advantage of the current opportunity that has been presented; he wants to profit from this collaboration and see improvements in his neighbourhood.

loans.use: For the purchase of seeds and nutrients necessary for the production of peppers

loans.use: To purchase seeds and nutrients necessary for the production of peppers

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia D. C., 35, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Reigerick D. C., a sewage worker, and they are blessed with a child in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have better lives. She has been managing her own tailoring shop for quite some time now.

Delia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her tailoring shop.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 8,000-Philippine-peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy raw materials needed to continue operations of the shop, like fabrics, thread, accessories, etc.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying raw materials needed to continue operations of the shop, like fabrics, thread, accessories, etc.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam R. has been spending her life cultivating vegetables. This is a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young. Also, she cuts and sells the crops to the market retailer when they come to maturity. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. 

She is married and has two kids; both are no longer in school and are employed. Her husband works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual activity with which she has had great success. The coming rainfall is good for growing, however, Sam R. doesn’t have capital yet to use on her farm. So, Sam R. is looking for a loan to use toward purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds for planting. She wishes to repair her old house by using the remaining money from the loan.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds for planting

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda S., 41, is making sure that her family has enough provisions to meet their daily needs. Married to Florante S., a taxi driver, they are blessed with one child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  To this end, Luzviminda has been managing her own tailoring shop for the past couple of years.

Luzviminda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her tailoring shop.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business and to buy raw supplies needed for her shop such as fabrics and thread. She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful. She hopes to start expanding her business in the very near future.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw supplies needed for her shop such as fabrics and thread.

loans.name: Hayanhyarvaa

texts.en: Hayanhyarvaa B. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been operating a public transport service between the two biggest markets, Harhorin and Narantuul, since 1999. He purchased another microbus via leasing in 2004 and uses his two buses for his transportation business. Hayanhyarvaa's wife helps him by working as a conductress. Hayanhyarvaa works very hard and is a silent, modest person. He says, “My only wish is to save the advance payment to purchase a recently imported micro bus via leasing”. He is requesting a 1,000,000MNT loan to purchase some construction materials to build a garage for his new buses.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
Eufemia C., 52, is making sure that her family has enough provisions to meet their daily needs. To this end, she has been managing her own sticky rice cake business for quite some time now.

Eufemia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her rice cake business.     

To ensure the success of her business, Eufemia would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business and to buy raw ingredients needed to continue producing her rice cakes. She will be buying sticky rice, sugar, coconut milk and other needed ingredients. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can renovate her house and hopes to have more patrons who will continue to buy her products.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw ingredients needed to continue producing her rice cakes.

Viviana makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. To this end, she has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Viviana has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, Viviana would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business and by buying the groceries needed to increase and replenish her current product inventory. She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries needed to increase and replenish her current product inventory.

loans.name: Chim

texts.en: Mr. Chim C. is a local farmer who grows a few vegetables to earn a living. He is 44 years old and has established a small family home with other family members. His wife works on the field with him. They are good parents who have tried to earn money to feed their four children since they were young. One of their children is now married and the other three are single. The approaching rainy season is the time Chim C. would normally grow his crops, but he does not have enough supplies to use on his farm. For this reason, Chim C. is applying for a $250 loan to help him buy supplies to plant vegetable crops.

loans.use: To buy supplies to grow vegetable crops.

loans.name: Rhodora

texts.en:
Rhodora B., 53, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Elpidio B., they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn money so that their family can have a better life.  She has been doing direct selling of popular brands of clothing and cosmetics for the past few years.

Rhodora has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her direct selling business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 20,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying advance orders of products from her direct selling line.

Rhodora dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buying advance orders of products from her direct selling line

loans.name: Enhzaya

texts.en: Enhzaya G. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and 3-year-old child in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Enhzaya operates a used clothing retail business in the Narantuul market, one of the largest and most crowded markets in Ulaanbaatar. She began her business in 2005 and now she works at a rented stall at Harhorin Market and is getting more customers every day. This successful business has allowed Enhzaya and her husband to buy their own ger where the family lives. Enhzaya would one day like to have her own workplace. She is a very hard working and easygoing person. Her husband helps to pick up items from wholesalers and they sell together at the market.  “What we want is to expand our business and possess our own shoe store someday, ” Enhzaya says. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase men's shoes for spring and fall at wholesale prices.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Enh-Undral

texts.en:
Enh-Undral G. is 23 years old and lives with her family in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. Her family operates a grocery business in their own container in the town. Her father is a truck driver and operates a transportation business throughout the province.

Enh-Undral began her business in 2004 with the help of her mother and has become very established in the many years since. She plants vegetables in the summertime in order to supplement her business earnings and has become successful in that endeavor as well. Enh-Undral is very modest and dreams of having a profession. She would like to expand her business even further in the future by building a greenhouse and a storehouse and is requesting a 1,945,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more products and vegetables in bulk for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more products and vegetables

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. B. has been in the farming business for years. Since 1979, she has planted various crops to earn a living. Her husband (in the photo) works with her on the farming business. This older couple has been married for years and has a child who is already married. B. has been spending her life cultivating crops, a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young. B. faces a problem: her farmland is located far from the watering system so the crops often do not grow well. To resolve this obstacle, B. is pursuing a loan to purchase a machine to irrigate her crops.

loans.use: To purchase a machine to irrigate her crops

loans.name: Rashdan's Group

texts.en:
Rashdan lives in the city of Multan with her husband and children. She operates a little boutique in her home to financially support her husband. She displays her embroidered dresses and stitched clothes in the boutique. She has always wanted to have this business because she is talented in this work. She can make all the designer dresses without any particular guidance. She mentioned that this is a God-gifted talent, which she enjoys having.

Rashdan takes orders from people in her area and fills them on time to make a better life for her family. Now she wants to buy another sewing machine and plans to hire a tailor to fill larger orders on time. She is hopeful that in this way she can increase her household income and also improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase another sewing machine

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina lives in Multan Pakistan, which is famous for its tombs and saint places. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over six years. She is a very caring lady. She not only manages her house efficiently but also operates a business selling clothes. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. Her husband feels proud of her supportive behavior towards him and the family.  

She takes orders from families of the neighboring areas and delivers them the clothes to earn an income. 
These days she has little stock and can't complete the orders of her customers. Therefore, she has applied for a loan from Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan) to buy the clothes in bulk. This will minimize her costs of traveling and also increase her ability to sell. She is hopeful that this investment will put new life in her business and she will be able to grow her income.

loans.use: Purchase clothes in bulk for reselling.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda A., 44, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Rolly A., 47, a jeepney driver, they are blessed with four children. Managing her own rag-making business for four years now, Stephanie makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that her family can have a better life. 

Luzviminda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, regularly attending their weekly fellowship meetings and consistently paying her weekly dues. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow six times in CCT’s Cooperative, using the money she borrows to expand and improve her business.

To ensure the continued success of her business, she is now requesting a PHP 12,000 loan to be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business. Luzviminda will buy replenishment stock for her variety store. 

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a education for her children and be able to live a well-off life.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Towards buying additional threads, clothes and other related materials for sewing round rags.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim N. is a 37-year-old married woman and local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. She planted rice and vegetable crops two months ago, but her crops are not growing well because they need more fertilizer. To remedy the situation, she would like a loan to buy two sacks of fertilizer and to hire a domestic laborer to plow the rest of her farmland so that she can plant crops. Sim N. and her husband are picture at their field.

loans.use: To buy two sacks of fertilizer.

loans.name: Chem

texts.en: The photograph shows Mrs. Chem S. at work raising pigs in her stall. Chem S. is a single mother who earns her daily revenue by working as a farmer in the local village; she raises pigs as well as cultivating a rice crop. Chem S. has given birth to five children: one is married and lives separately and the others are still single. Chem S. has always been successful with her pig-raising investment because she learned how to do it years ago. To earn additional income, Chem S. is applying for a loan to buy pig feed and more piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and more piglets to raise.

loans.name: Bizard

texts.en:
Bizard E., 36, is making sure that his family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Marlyn E., 36, a plain housewife, they are blessed with two children. Managing his own upholstery business for 19 years now, Bizard makes sure that he earns well so that his family can have a better life. 


Bizard has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, regularly attending their weekly fellowship meetings and consistently paying his weekly dues. Because of his good repayment performance with his previous loans, he has been able to borrow nine times in CCT’s Cooperative, using the money he borrows to expand and improve his business.


To ensure the continued success of his business, he is now requesting a PHP 18,000 loan to be used as a source of added capital for his expanding business. Bizard will buy raw materials needed for his upholstery business. He dreams that his business will continue to grow so that he can provide an education for his children. He dreams of being able to attain financial security, a debt-free life.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Towards buying raw materials for upholstery buiness.

loans.name: Choeurn

texts.en: Choeurn H. and her husband (in photo) live in Kompong Tom province, Cambodia, where they have owned a plot of land since 2001. They raise crops and pigs, who reach productivity twice a year. In addition, Choeurn H.’s husband also buys animals to resell for extra income. Choeurn H. and her husband are good parents to their two school-aged children. In view of the fact that animal selling is profitable, Choeurn H. is applying for a loan for her husband to use as capital to buy animals to resell.

loans.use: To buy animals to resell

loans.name: Bano's Group

texts.en:
Bano is the wife of M. Z. and lives in Multan, the city of sweetmeats and holy places in Pakistan. She owns a small house with two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over ten years.  

Bano is a caring lady.  She is a very good mother who takes care of her children and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife. 

Her husband has a mobile phone shop in the market. He sells new and used handsets. His customer service is very good. Other shop keepers come to him to seek guidance in handsets because he has been doing this work for the last eight years.  

Bano has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) for her husband's mobile phone shop. With the loan, he will increase his mobile phone variety which will attract more customers to his shop and increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phones to sell.

loans.name: Semuuhen

texts.en:
Semuuhen N. is 55 years-old and lives with her family in Uvs province in western Mongolia. She and her family, a total of ten persons, live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. 

Since 2006, she has been selling a variety of socks outside of the local market and shops. Her husband is a driver for a local construction company and earns 250,000 MNT salary per month. Their daughter supports her trading business and has contributed  500,000 MNT to her parents. Semuuhen was ill in 2009 and had medical treatment in Ulaanbaatar.  She says “now I am recovered and happy to live with my big family”.  

Semuuhen is a hardworking and optimistic woman.  She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase three sacks of socks in Ulaanbaatar at wholesale prices and she will resell them at retail prices in her native town.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en:
Nergui B. is 35 years-old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of  Mongolia. Her eldest daughter attends middle school and her husband helps her with the family business. 

Nergui operates a dairy retail business in Harhorin, the second biggest market in Ulaanbaatar. She began the business in 1993 and purchased a stall where she sells products. Since then, her business has become very successful and in 2004, she purchased a plot of land where she and her family live and built a house which was completed in 2009. She says, “because my business has become so successful, our family has a plan to build our own small food store in the fence where we live”.  Nergui works very hard and is a very optimistic person. Nergui is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase construction and repair materials for her house.

loans.use: To purchase construction and repair materials for her house.

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en:
Mr. C. is an elderly man whose wife appears in the photo above.  They reside in an area of a Commune in Kompong Tom Province, where they have made a living raising rice and pigs since 2000.

In addition to their farming business, C. works as a district consultant advisor. He now has four children, two are married and the other two are still young and live in the family home. Because raising pigs is profitable, C. is taking out his first loan to purchase pig food and piglets for his pen.

loans.use: To purchase pig food and piglets.

loans.name: Tsetsegsuren

texts.en:
Tsetsegsuren V. lives with her sisters in the Central province of Mongolia in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. She operates a consumer goods retailing business. She began her business in 2003 with a working capital of 100,000 MNT. Since then, she has bought a grocery trading stall from which to operate her business and her working capital has grown to exceed 3,200,000 MNT.

Tsetsegsuren would like to grow her business in order to also sell dairy products and to be able to save money so that she can improve both her quality of life and to get married. In 2009, she purchased a Korean small car with her business profits in order to deliver consumer goods to her workplace. She is hard working and modest person. Tsetsegsuren is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a variety of dairy products at wholesale prices.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of dairy products.

loans.name: Zameeran's Group

texts.en:
Zameeran lives in Multan, Pakistan, with her family. She is the wife of K. H. and owns a small house of two rooms in an area named Qadirabad. She is a very talented lady. Despite working hard, she couldn’t upgrade her boutique business due to few financial resources. The amount she earns is utilized to meet the financial expenses of the family. She does this work to support her husband financially.  

She takes orders for her boutique from her neighborhood and earns income by fulfilling them. Many times, she fails to deliver an order to her customers due to the lack of variety. Therefore, she has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute and Kiva partner in Pakistan) to invest capital in her business. 

The loan amount will help her to buy more variety of clothes, clothing material and ready-made garments for her boutique, which will help in increasing her income and fulfilling the orders of her customers.

loans.use: Purchase required material for boutique

loans.name: Jaime Yasir

texts.es: Jaime Yasir E. H. de 35 años de edad, vive junto a su grupo familiar, el cual esta conformado por su esposa, la cual se dedica a trabajar como profesora, así mismo junto a su hija de 12 años de edad, la cual se dedica a estudiar en la escuela que trabaja su madre. Jaime posee una tienda en la cual comercializa  diferentes productos de primera necesidad como granos básicos, jugos, productos para el hogar, entre otros más. El negocio es bastante completo, por lo que posee muchos clientes, los cuales son vecinos y personas de los alrededores de su casa, en donde se encuentra ubicada la tienda, la cual se encuentra en Ilobasco, departamento de Cabañas. Jaime ofrece muy buenos precios, los cuales son bastante accesibles y más bajos que los de su competencia, por lo que desea comprar mayor cantidad de productos y de esta forma ofrecerlos a precios aún más bajos. Jaime solicita un préstamo por medio del cual compre productos de primera necesidad por mayor, así mismo comprar productos que han sido lanzados al mercado recientemente y que son muy solicitados por los clientes y que aún no posee. Todo esto lo hace con el deseo de mejorar su negocio y de esta forma percibir mayores ganancias las cuales sean de gran beneficio para su familia y su hogar.
texts.en:
35-year-old Jaime Yasir E. H. lives with his family, which is comprised of his wife, who works as a teacher, and his 12-year-old daughter who studies at the school where her mother works. Jaime has a store in which he sells various basic necessities, such as dry beans and grains, juices, and home goods. He carries a wide array of goods, so he has a lot of customers among his neighbors and others near his home, where his store is located, in Ilobasco, department of Cabañas. Jaime offers good prices that are affordable and lower than those of his competition. Therefore, he wishes to buy greater quantities of his goods, so he can offer even lower prices. Jaime is seeking a loan in order to buy basic goods wholesale, as well as to buy goods recently launched on the market that are in much demand by his customers and that he still does not have. He does all this with the desire to improve his business in order to increase his profits, which will be very beneficial for his family and home.

Translated from Spanish by Jacqueline Demeranville, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic necessities

loans.name: Duong Nhan 1-2 Group

texts.en:
Ngu D. N. was born in 1959. He lives in Duong Nhan village, Xuan Non commune. He is a farmer. He has two sons. 

He not only grows rice and raise pigs, he also catches fish to sell. He has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnam dong (VND). 

His life is difficult. So, he has to work hard to earn money. He has punctually participated in SEDA (a Kiva partner) since 2007. He feels happy because he can save money weekly. In this loan cycle, he would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to buy food for pigs.
 
About the other borrowers in his group: 

Thach T. N. was born in1970. She has two children (a girl and a son). She breeds pigs and poultry. She has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She would like to borrow 4,142,000 VND in order to invest in livestock.

Thuy T. N. was born in 1965. She raises pigs. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy food for pigs.

loans.use: To buy food for pigs

loans.name: Leak

texts.en:
Buying and selling animals is part of 31-year-old Mr. Leak S.’s daily routine. Leak S. always leaves home to buy animals and fatten them for a while at his house before selling them to gain income. 

He has another financial earner in his wife, who sells Khmer noodles in the village. This couple has two kids who are still young and not enrolled in school. 

Because his current business is the main financial contributor for his family, Leak S. wants to accumulate its capital and sustain its growth. Leak S. is asking for a loan in order to purchase more animals, such as cows and water buffalo, to resell to raise profit. 

Leak S. was not available when the photo taken, so his wife and their children are pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase more animals to resell

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is a farmer from the town of Nyamira in western Kenya. He is 47 years old and married with four children between the ages of 1½ and 20. Three of his children are currently attending school.

Samwel has been practicing mixed farming for 22 years and has employed two people from his community. His products are maize, beans, tea, coffee, and pineapples, which he sells to the local market. He relies on the income from farming to cater for the family's basic needs.

His major challenges in this business are too much rainfall, which destroys his crops, and lack of fertilizers during the planting season.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 45,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. With this loan, he will be able to purchase a quality cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The extra income from this loan will assist in paying school fees for his children.

In the future, he hopes to acquire more dairy cows that will improve his productivity. He appreciates what Juhudi has done for him and his family.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is a citizen of the city of Multan in Pakistan. She owns a small two-room house in an area named Qadir Abad and has lived with her family for over fifteen years.

Nasreen operates a business selling clothes. She also has sewing skills and offers her clients sewing services for a reasonable charge. The quality, well-stitched clothes attract her more customers.

She travels to Faisalabad (famous for its textiles) and Lahore (famous for new designs and fashion) to purchase clothes. She has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) for her business. With the loan, she will buy clothes in bulk to minimize the cost of travel and increase the variety of clothes for sale. Nasreen Bibi is hopeful about the future of her business—that she will earn good profit from it and also increase her customers.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for selling

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Nyoliana

texts.en:
Nyoliana is 38 years old. She is a single mother of two children, ages 11 and 18. Both children are attending school.

She is a farmer from Nyamira town in Western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for five years. Her products are maize, milk, tea and beans, which she sells to the local market. She also runs a shop, where she earns 15,000 Kenyan shillings per month.

Her major challenges in farming are the diseases, which affect her crops and animals, and the unpredictable weather conditions, which affect her produce.

Nyoliana has successfully completed a previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 45,000 and has requested this loan for Kes. 70,000 to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will assist her in paying school fees for her children and improving their living standards.

In the future, she hopes to be selling her products on a wholesale basis.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Ms. Juliana P. is from the barangay (village) of Bolinsong, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years of age and is single. Juliana is presently engaged in operating a sari-sari (variety) store business where she sells items such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste and much more. She has been engaged in this kind of business for four years already and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from sales. In 2009, Juliana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Juliana is now requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to add her the capital of her sari-sari store business. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, as savings for future use, especially for future business expansion, and for her niece and nephew’s education. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
Samina lives with her family in the city of Multan, famous for its sweetmeats and saints' places. Her husband is a rickshaw driver and she supports him by running a boutique in her home. Her embroidered dresses are famous among her relatives and within her community. She is excellent at her work and receives a good amount of orders from her neighbors. Despite her elderly age, she works with energy and enthusiasm. This is the reason for the success of her business: she takes good orders from her customers and completes them on time. Her daughters have the advantage of learning this art from her and every day she teaches them a new embroidery technique.

Samina has applied for a loan from Asasah / Kiva for her husband. He will use the loan amount to overhaul and maintain his rickshaw. She is hopeful that by repairing the rickshaw, her husband will be able to work better and bring more money home.

loans.use: Repair a rickshaw

loans.name: Primitiva Elcarte's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Primitiva E., 57 years of age, is married and is a resident of Purok 3, Cabunga-an, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Primitiva is the group leader of this two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if they are delinquent or default. The official name of this borrowing group is Primitiva E.’s Group.

Primitiva is married to Lerio E., a motor cab driver. They are blessed with five children of whom two are already married and three are now adults.

To help her husband, Primitiva decided to engage in a micro-business, particularly in operating a sari-sari (variety) store and some farming activity. For a year, already, she has been able to maintain the said business activity and now she is earning an average net income of not less than P3,000 a month which is so helpful to their family income.

Primitiva joined the Cooperative in 2009. As an active member of the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) Program of Paglaum MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting an amount of P10,000 as her 3rd loan. Part will be used in purchasing commercial fertilizers and the remaining amount added to the capital of her sari-sari store.

The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions of Primitiva’s family, to meet their basic needs, for loan repayments to PMPC, and for possible business expansion.

loans.use: To purchase commercial fertilizers and to use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

location.town: P3 Cabunga-an, Clarin, Mis. Occ., Mindanao

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy is 41 years old and married with 4 children between the ages of 4 and 17. All the children are currently attending school.

Kennedy is a farmer from the town of Nyamira in Western Kenya. He has been farming for 15 years and has employed 4 people from his community. His products are tea, milk, maize, beans and poultry, which he sells to the local market. He is also a certified veterinary officer employed by the government. His biggest challenge in farming is the limited market for his products since most people have their own farms.

Kennedy has a good record with Juhudi Kilimo after he successfully completed a previous loan for KES 45,000. He has requested this loan for KES 70,000 to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help him improve his productivity and enhance the marketability of his products.

Kennedy is happy with the services he receives and is willing to expand his farming business. He also plans to own a cooling plant in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her poultry project and build a dairy unit

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her poultry project

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She lives with her mother and two siblings. She has owned her lingerie store for the past 8 years. She is now requesting to borrow $800 to increase her merchandise.

loans.use: to increase her merchandise

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 42-year-old married woman with six children in school. She has been operating a salon for the past five years. She also sells charcoal to earn extra income. Her husband assists her in managing her business together with three other employees.

Elizabeth is a member of Kyumbi Ebenezer group with Faulu Kenya; the members guarantee each other's loans. She has requested a loan of KES 70,000 to buy salon equipment. She hopes to educate her children to university level in the future. She also dreams of owning a plot of land in the future.

loans.use: To purchase salon equipment

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 42-year-old married woman with three children in school. She has been running a green grocer shop for five years. She plans to expand her business so that she can get more income in the future.  Therefore, she has requested a loan of KES 40,000 from Faulu Kenya. She has been guaranteed by the Furaha Ladies' group in Faulu Kenya because she is a member of the group. She believes that the loan will help her move her business to a higher level.

loans.use: To expand the business premises

loans.name: Hor

texts.en: Mrs. Hor S., 53, owns and operates a handicraft business whose main activity is selling rattan cupboards. She sells rattan that her husband weaves or that she orders from other weavers who live in the village. She and her husband use their horse cart as transportation and it takes a week to sell all their rattan. This couple has five children: two are now married and the other three are single. Two children are employed. Recently, Hor S. got orders from her clients, but she doesn't have enough product to fill the demand. Therefore, Hor S. has requested a loan as capital to purchase more rattan cupboards to better meet her customers' needs.

loans.use: To purchase more rattan cupboards to better meet her customers' needs

loans.name: Akwata Empola Gayaza, Kampala Group

texts.en:
Her down-the-line hard work and self-assured attitude has been her winning calling card in a five-year-old restaurant business in Gayaza, Kampala. This has been the bedrock for the growth of 40-year-old K. Martha’s business.

Basking in the glow of a good marriage has also, in a way, contributed to the stability and longevity of Martha’s business. With the support of her husband, who has always been at her beck and call, this mother of four has gone out of her way to fend off the many challenges that have come her way.

In a week, Martha says she makes profits in the range of 70,000 shillings and she is hoping for improved and fresh conditions on the acquisition of this loan. She started off with a clothes-selling business that she dispensed with after much second thought. With this loan, which is her second, she wants to buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs like bananas, beans, soya beans, meat, cassava, etc., for her restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 23-year old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and three siblings, and tries to help his father with the family expenses.

In 2003 he started working with a friend painting houses. Four years later after making his own connections he started working on his own.

He is now requesting a $500 loan to purchase a new machine for painting houses, which will help him become more efficient.

loans.use: To purchase a painting machine for his housepainting business.

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en:
Shahida lives with her husband and children in Multan, Pakistan, the city of sweetmeats and shrines. 

A very talented lady, Shahida owns and operates a boutique business. She first buys unstitched clothes from the market and then stitches them with good designs to sell to her customers. She has been doing this work for over five years.

She is acknowledged in her community as a hardworking lady. Her business helps her to improve the living standard of her family. She has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest more capital in her boutique business. She will buy clothes and threads in bulk with the loan amount. 

She is hopeful that with this loan she will be able to achieve her goal of having a successful boutique business.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for her sewing business.

loans.name: Isabel's Group

texts.en: Isabel A. is from the village of Poblacion. She is 50 years old and is the group leader of this three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Isabel is married and has two school-aged children. She owns and operates a business selling fresh ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Isabel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Isabel is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used for house repair. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Clarita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Clarita joined GDMPC to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.name: Koem

texts.en: Mr. K. is an older man whose wife appears on the photo. K. has learned a skill in building wooden houses and currently uses his knowledge to earn money. He has a few employees to help him. K. has one child still at home, while the other four children are ready married and have started new homes. He has a life partner in his wife who is a rattan cupboard maker. Recently, she received a big order from her customer but does not have the stock to fill it. Mr. K. is requesting a loan for his wife to order the raw materials to make cupboards for her client.

loans.use: To order raw material to make cupboards.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is married with ten children, all of them are at school. She has no additional family members to care for. Fatuma sells bananas in Nalukongo market. She buys bananas from Mbarara in southern Uganda and uses public transport to and from Mbarara. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She has been in this business for ten years. She pays monthly market dues of 45000/=. She has a water project where she gets some additional money. Fatuma sells both retail and wholesale. She works seven days a week. Fatuma depends on this job to get a living. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. Her business challenges are transportation and defaulters. Fatuma lives in a two-roomed house she owns and the family has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Juana Paquit's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Juana P., 56 years of age and married, is a resident of Catadman, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. Juana is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Juana P.’s Group.

Juana is married to Generoso P. who is a driver who earns an average income of not less than P170.00. They are blessed with eight children, five of whom are already married, one is single and two are in their teens. To help her husband, she decided to engage in micro-business particularly in snack vending and RTW (GTY products) dealing activity.  For 10 years, she has been able to maintain this business activity and she is earning an average net income of not less than P1,000.00 a month. 

This amount has been so helpful to their family income that she joined PMPC in 2007. As an active member of the PDP-LP Program of PMPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out the rural poor, she is requesting an amount of P6,000.00 as her fifth loan to be used for purchasing additional piglets for her piggery and for house repairs. The future income from this loan will be used to improve her family's living conditions, to meet their basic needs, loan repayments to PMPC and for possible business expansion.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for her piggery and for house repairs

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Men P. is a 42-year-old resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, where she earns a living by selling flowers for ceremonies and other parties at the local busy market. She married years ago and is blessed with two children, one of whom is married and the other is still a dependent. She has a life partner in her husband who is a military policeman. This is the second loan she has requested. Men P. will use this loan to purchase an old motorcycle to provide the transportation for her family, as well as to order more and different kinds of flowers to better meet her valued customers' requirements.

loans.use: To purchase an old motorcycle.

loans.name: Chhin

S. earns her living selling traditional cake, for which she is famous. She is very skilled and everyone appreciates her cake. She has a small plot of land along the village road, which she received from her parents. On her land, she always takes time to plant rice for the purpose of eating and selling. There is a plot of farmland in a good location for farming. S. wants to purchase this land to grow more rice so that she can have additional income. However, she does not have the money to buy it. This is why she has requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner, HKL.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with two children and both of them are at school.  She also takes care of additional family members.

Margaret owns a stall selling vaseline in Nalukolongo market.  These vaselines are locally made (from oil extracted from Carapa grandiflora tree seeds).  Margaret buys raw materials from Bugolobi in Kampala and she uses public transport to and from Bugolobi. She has been in this business for eleven years.  She plans to use the loan to buy more cans of raw materials.

Margaret pays daily market dues of 1000/= (Ugandan Shillings) per day worked. Her customers are the local people who are interested in her vaseline. She works six days a week and depends on this job to make a living. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees, food and medication.

Her major business challenges are transportation and lack of enough market for her vaseline. Margaret joined MCDT to acquire more capital and aspires to seeing her business grow bigger and start packing and selling her product wholesale. Margaret resides in and owns a three-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water.

loans.use: To buy more cans of raw materials for making vaseline

loans.name: Josphat

texts.en:

He is an active member of the Kyumbi Ebenezer group in Faulu Kenya and has had six loans through the group.  He has requested a loan of 50,000 KES to purchase cameras, printers and film for his business to run smoothly.  He hopes to buy another piece of land for business purpose so as to increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase cameras, printers and film

loans.name: Jingo

texts.en:
Jingo A. is married and has six children, all of whom are currently in school. In addition, she takes care of two other family members. She rents and resides in a one-room house, though her family has no access to electricity and piped water.

To earn a living, she sells charcoal at her home in Nalukolongo, Lubaga Division, Kampala District. To do so, she uses public transportation to get to and from the villages of Luwero district, where she purchases her charcoal. She explains that she sells charcoal seven days a week to all kinds of customers (i.e., both retail and wholesale), and that her customers are all local people. She has been in this line of business for 15 years.

She is now seeking a loan to buy more bags of charcoal. Her business challenges include transportation costs and the rainy season. Her highest monthly expenses are school fees and the rent for her home.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional charcoal
