loans.name: Ramiriza Group

texts.fr:
Marie Claire N. est une commerçante âgée de 29ans qui habite la Commune de Kanyosha en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de charbon au quartier Kanyosha à Bujumbura. C’est un métier qu’elle exerce depuis 2 ans alors qu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 7e année. Son époux, N., est un chauffeur. Elle arrive au 6e cycle avec le crédit de Turame. 

Elle est mère de 3 garçons âgés respectivement de 6 ans, 3 ans et 1 année  3mois. L’aîné est à l’école. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour changer le type de business en achetant des habits pour les revendre au marche Central de Bujumbura. Elle espère ainsi que cela lui permettra d’acquérir une plus grande capacité de générer du bénéfice pour parvenir à construire sa propre maison. Elle a l’espoir que ses enfants finiront les études avec succès et  être capables de lui venir en aide dans le futur a cote de mener une vie meilleure. Elle va continuer à demander le crédit Turame car il est le plus préfère aux autres institutions financières car les conditions d’accès et de remboursement sont plus faciles. Elle conseille à tous ceux qui veulent pratiquer le commerce que la persévérance est la clé du succès dans ce métier 

 Elle est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « Ramiriza » qui veut dire « Continuer ».
texts.en:
Marie Claire N. is a 29-year-old merchant living in Kanyosha, a borough which is part of the Bujumbura mayorship. She has been selling coal in Kanyosha for the past two years, before which she was a cash crop farmer. She went to school until the 7th grade. Her husband N. is a driver. She is now in her sixth loan cycle with Turame. She is the mother of three boys who are 6 years, 3 years, and 1 year and 3 months old. The eldest attends school. She is requesting the Kiva loan to change her business activity and buy clothing for resale at the central market in Bujumbura. She hopes that this will increase her ability to generate revenue so that she can eventually build her own home. She hopes that her children will successfully complete their schooling and become able in the future to help her lead a better life. She will continue to request loans from Turame because their terms for loans and repayments are easier to handle than with other financial institutions. She advises those who wish to practice a commercial activity that perseverance is the key to success in this profession. She is a member of the “Ramizira” community group, which means “Continue”.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: changer le type de business en achetant des habits pour les revendre au marche Central de Bujumbura

loans.name: Abateesa Kabowa Group, Kampala

texts.en:
N. Nadima is an extraordinarily enterprising woman. She has just clocked that shady side of 60 but still remains actively involved in her eight-year-old retail shop business in Kabowa, Kampala. She is a widow with over sixteen children.

The reality of taking care of all these children without the support of her late husband has been a hard one to look in the face. It has been incumbent upon her to nurture, clothe, educate and provide food to them. This business has in many ways been her recourse despite the paltry 800,000 shillings she makes in a month. Paltry in the sense that she also has relatives looking up to her.

Combining the two tasks has been a tall order but, thanks to her pragmatic and philosophical attitude towards issues, she has made lots of headway. What has also helped has been the fact that she has been eking out other invaluable profits from her farming business. She started off her business journey with a now-closed hardware shop.

With this loan, N. wants to principally purchase more cosmetics and other popular retail goods for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics and other retail items for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 46-year old single man from Lebanon. He worked in a small restaurant for the past eleven years, and one year ago he opened his own cafeteria.

He is now requesting to borrow $1,000 in order to purchase needed supplies for his business.

loans.use: to purchase needed supplies

loans.name: Lan

texts.en: Lan T. K. N. was born in 1966 and lives in Xuan Non village. She has two sons, one is married while her younger son attends school. Her husband is a contractor. Her family has a mechanic shop where she works. She has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 Vietnam dong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2003 and has been punctual. In this loan, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND in order to invest in her mechanic shop.

loans.use: To invest in her mechanic shop

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a single mother of six children and all of them are in school. She also takes care of additional family members. She rents and resides in a two-room house and the family has access to electricity. 

Jane Sells bark cloth in Nalukolongo road along the Masaka – Kampala road.  She buys these bark cloths from people who get them from Masaka and Rakai districts in central eastern Uganda. (Bark cloth is a textile-like material made from bark stripped from the Ficus Natalensis tree.)

She has been in this business for ten years. She plans to use the loan to buy more pieces of bark cloth to increase her stock. Her customers are the local people who have lost their loved ones. She works six days a week and depends on this job to make a living.  She hopes to start going directly to Masaka for bark cloth to sell. Jane joined MCDT to boost her business by getting additional capital.

loans.use: To buy more pieces of bark cloth

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine has been in the business of selling spare parts for a long time. She is 35 years old and married. Vestine works hard every day in order to expand her business. She works from morning hours until late in the evening hours.

Vestine is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business meaningfully. With this loan, Vestine will purchase additional spare parts to sell. She really hopes that her sales will increase as well as her profits. Vestine will keep reinvesting the profits in her business for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy a variety of spare parts

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
Jalia is a single mother of five children and all of them are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members. 

Jalia operates a charcoal store in her home in Nalukolongo, Lubaga Division, Kampala District.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She has been in this business for ten years.  

Besides this charcoal business she also owns rental rooms which bring in additional income to the family. Jalia sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. She buys bags of charcoal from the Mubende District and uses public transport to and from Mubende.  She is hoping to own a delivery van in the future. Her customers are the local people around the area. She works seven days a week. 

Jalia joined MCDT because she wanted to get additional capital for her business.  She rents and resides in a one-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent, school fees and food.  Her business challenges include transportation and the rainy season which hinders her movements in the village.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Marie Florence

texts.fr: S. Marie Florence est née en 1983 au Benin. Marie Florence vit depuis dix ans au quartier Dédokpo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Marie Florence est mariée à TOTTIN Fidèle, un guérisseur traditionnel. Marie Florence est mère d'un enfant scolarisé. Marie Florence partage les charges familiales avec son mari. La famille vit ensemble. Marie Florence exerce depuis huit ans au grand marché international du Bénin (Dantokpa), comme activité principale la vente de divers produits (mayonnaise, lait, sucre, moutarde, petits pois, concombre, berterave, carottes, choux, pommes de terre, etc.). Marie Florence s'approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. Marie Florence a déja bénéficié de quatre concours financiers auprès de ALIDé avec un bon remboursement. C'est toujours pour accroitre son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle que Marie Florence sollicite un nouveau prèt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Marie Florence S. was born in 1983 in Benin. She has lived for ten years in the Dédokpo borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Fidèle TOTTIN, a traditional healer. She is the mother of one child attending school. The family lives together, and Marie Florence shares family expenses with her husband. For the past eight years Marie Florence’s main activity has been the retail commerce of various food products (mayonnaise, milk, sugar, peas, cucumbers, beets, carrots, cabbages, potatoes, etc.) at the great international market of Benin: Dantokpa. She gets her supplies from Lomé in Togo, a neighbouring country. Marie Florence has already been granted four financial loans from ALIDé which were reimbursed satisfactorily. She is now requesting another loan from ALIDé, with the view of increasing her business activity and providing a better response to her customer's demands.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products (potatoes, cabbages, carrots, mayonnaise, milk, peas, etc.)

loans.name: Tuyet

texts.en: Tuyet T. N. was born in 1962. Not only does she grow rice but she also raises poultry. She has two sons, the older son works for a factory near their house and the younger son goes to school. She wants to have a better life so she tries to work. She has participated in SEDA since 2003 and has always repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND to invest in her livestock (poultry).

loans.use: To invest in livestock (poultry)

loans.name: Concerned Mothers, Kampala Group

texts.en:
Halima K. has made it a routine to take painstaking stock of her business plans at the end of every passing operating month. This has, to a great degree, lent her that survival countenance in her seven-year-old hardware business in Zana, Kampala.

The reason why most businesses around her locality have unraveled is because most people who embark on doing business don’t have solid blueprint plans drawn up to help their businesses succeed, not only in the short run, but also in the long term. Most are just out to make quick profits. K. is an exception to this rule as she comes up with daily and end of month plans and objectives aimed at elevating her business.

This mother of three has showed her worth in a business sector dominated by men. To get where she is today, she had to start off small. She recalls with nostalgia her first business: clothes sales. With savings from this and with the support of her husband, she made her plans of owning and running a hardware shop come to fruition.

In a week, K. makes sufficient profits to the tune of 500,000 shillings. Her sense of optimism is sky high, knowing that, with this loan, she is going to make strides in terms of improving her business. She is anticipating purchasing items like paint and cement in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase items like paint and cement in bulk

loans.name: Nghiep

texts.en: Nghiep T. D. was born in 1952. She grows rice and breeds pigs. She has three children who are married. Her husband is a moto and bicycle repair worker. He has a daily income. Her family has a monthly income of about 4,500,000 Vietnam dong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2003 and has repaid punctually. She wants to participate in SEDA forever because she can save money per week. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 8,066,000 VND to buy pig food.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Jaqueline

texts.en:
Jaqueline is 30 years old, is single, and lives with her parents. She owns a business selling various clothes; in this business she has an experience of seven years and employs one person as a helper. Her business starts at seven in the morning and runs to eight in the evening every day except Saturday. Her business is profitable but, unfortunately, she has only a small amount of capital invested in it.

Jaqueline is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business which will allow her to earn more profits. She expects to reinvest this profit in her business.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en:
T. Immaculate has been toiling hard for the last five years operating her food stall business in Bisheshe, Ibanda. She has mostly been selling tomatoes, avocados, cabbages and soya beans.

Despite the threat of pests and fluctuations in the local market prices of most of the goods that she sells, Immaculate has persisted, well knowing that she has responsibilities that lie ahead of her. She has two children and one dependent to take care of.

Given the variety of fruits, vegetables and other foods that she sells, Immaculate has managed to attract and hold her own big and reliable share of clients. These have been the reason why her business has survived and is still standing.

In a month, given the unpredictability of the seasons, Immaculate says she makes profits totaling to 120,000 shillings or even more. She is full of hope that this loan will help her strength her business further, as she will be able to buy foodstuffs on a larger scale.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell such as cassava, potatoes, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married man from Lebanon, living with his wife. He started working in a car body repair shop in 2002, and opened his own shop in 2005.

He is now requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase new equipment for his business.

loans.use: to purchase new equipment

loans.name: Célestine

texts.fr: H. Célestine est née le 1er janvier 1983 au Bénin. Célestine est mariée à KPATOUKPA Urbain. Célestine est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Célestine vit depuis douze ans à Djidjè un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Célestine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Célestine vient en aide à son mari, en ce qui concerne les différentes charges de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Célestine vend en effet, des chaussures à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est à Lomé au TOGO, pays voisin du Bénin que Célestine achète ses articles. Célestine avait déjà contracté deux crédits auprès de ALIDé et les a tous bien remboursés. En vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire les exigences de sa clientèle, Célestine sollicite un nouveau crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Célestine H. was born 1 January 1983 in Benin. She is married to Urbain KPATOUKPA, and is the mother of two children, both attending school. Célestine has been living for 12 years in the Djidjè borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She lives with her children and her husband, and helps her husband manage the various family expenses, thanks to the income generated by her activity. Indeed, she sells shoes in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and gets her supplies from Lomé in Togo, a country neighbouring Benin. Célestine had already been granted two loans from ALIDé, and repaid both in full. She is now requesting another loan to increase the level of her activity and provide a better response to customer demand.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes

loans.name: Magbesseh Group

texts.en:
These are the members of the “Magbesseh” group. They are small-scale businesswomen in Magburaka town who have applied for a loan of SLL 2,000,000 from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses and make more sales and better profits.

Fatmata B. (shown on the left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Masang, a village near Magburaka. She is approximately 40 years of age, married to a businessman, and they have five children; two of her children are attending primary school and three are in secondary school. 

Fatmata sells vegetable oil, groundnuts (peanuts) and Margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste). Fatmata has had many years of experience in business. With her share of this loan, she will buy more oil, groundnuts and Margi in large quantity to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable oil, groundnuts and Margi in large quantities

loans.name: Kamuyusu Group

texts.en:
Issa T. (pictured third from left) is the leader of this group. Born in Mayorloh, on the outskirts of Magburaka town, the 29-year-old father of five sells shoes, cloths, trousers, toothpaste, toothbrushes, etc. He has been running this business for nine years now. With the help of this loan, Issa will be able to expand his business by buying the above mentioned items in large quantity. This will lead to an increase in sales and profit and Issa will thus be in a better position to look after his children, two of whom are in primary school, one in secondary school and the other one still an infant. 

This group is named "Kamuyusu", a Temne phrase meaning “Be Patient With Us”. The members are all local entrepreneurs in Magburaka, the headquarter town of the Tonkolili district in Northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of 800,000 leones each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy shoes, cloths, trousers, toothpaste, toothbrushes, etc.

loans.name: Sorry For Me Ii Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the members of the “Sorry For Me II” group. They are small-scale businesspeople who are based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Idrissa K. who is pictured second from the right. He is age 40 and was born in Magburaka town. He is married with seven children. His wife is a businesswoman and his children are attending both primary and secondary schools.

Idrissa sells gold, palm-oil, groundnuts (peanuts), etc. He will use his share of the loan to buy tons of gold from gold miners in neighboring villages.

loans.use: To buy tons of gold from gold miners in neighboring villages

loans.name: Rashid S.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the T.D.E.C Primary School, Magburaka, which was founded in 1959. The school is staffed with 327 pupils and seventeen teachers. Out of the seventeen teachers, these ten have applied for a loan from Kiva lenders through SMT.

This is the first loan members of this institution are accessing from Kiva lenders through SMT. With the help of this loan, some members of staff will start a small business and those who are already running small businesses will invest the loan in their business. Some of the staff members will be using the loan to buy pieces of furniture, others to pay either for their children’s education or pay for themselves to pursue further studies. Others will use their loan in home building projects.

Fifty-one-year-old Rashid S. K. (whose photo is attached at the top left) is the leader of this group. He was born in a place called Maworr and is married with four children. Rashid will use part of his loan to buy house building materials and invest part in an agricultural project.

loans.use: To buy house building materials and to invest  in an agricultural project

loans.name: Tamaraneh Traders Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesswomen in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 800,000, they will be able to add more stock to their business, make more sales, and make more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by feeding and clothing their children and sending them to school.

Adama T. is the leader of this group. She was born in a place called Mayboll, 38 years ago. She is married and has five children. Her husband is a medical practitioner and her children are attending schools – four in secondary schools and one in primary school.

Adama sells items like groundnuts (peanuts), beans and palm-oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil) and has been doing this business for ten years now. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying wholesale more groundnuts, beans and palm-oil.

loans.use: To buy wholesale more groundnuts, beans and palm-oil

loans.name: One To Two Group

texts.en:
This is Sinmnah K., Memunatu K., Josephine C., Baby B. and Mamusu K.. Sinmnah K. is the leader of the group.

Sinmnah has been a businesswoman for five years now and owns a “cigarette box” where she sells cigarettes, biscuits, mints, chewing gum, matches, blades, etc. She is 28 years of age and her husband is a tailor. She has three children, two of whom are attending primary school. She was born in Magburaka town, the Tonkolili district headquarters town.

Sinmnah will use this loan to further expand her business inventory. She will buy the above mentioned items wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy more cigarettes, biscuits, mints, chewing gum, matches, blades, etc. for her store

loans.name: Masianday Ii Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “Masianday II” group. They are small-scale-business people in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and make better profits. Consequently, their living standards will improve and they will at least be able to provide three meals a day for their children, pay their schools fees, buy them clothes to wear, and pay their medical bills in case any of them fall sick.

Kadiatu C. is the leader of this group. She was born in Bumbuna, about 35 miles from Magburaka. She is 38 years of age, is married to a businessman, and they have four children – two in secondary school and two in primary school.

Kadiatu sells chewing gum, cigarettes, bathing soap, batteries, biscuits, rice, etc., and has been a businesswoman for twelve years now. With her share of the loan, she will increase her business inventory by buying wholesale the above mentioned items.

loans.use: To buy chewing gum, cigarettes, bathing soap, batteries, biscuits, rice, etc., for her store

loans.name: Kuru Masaba Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Kuru Masaba” group. They are small-scale-business women based in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Aminata K.. Aminata is age 23; she was born in Magburaka. Her husband is a motorbike driver and her two children are attending primary school.

For four years now, Aminata has sold shoes. With her share of the loan, she will invest in her business by buying shoes wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more shoes wholesale to sell

loans.name: Kick Poor United Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Kick Poor United” group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty-businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, in order to seek for a loan of SLL 2,700,000 for the entire group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Issa L., pictured in the middle. Issa was born in Magburaka town about 38 years ago. He is married and has five children. His wife is a businesswoman and three of his children attend school – one in primary school and two in secondary school. For nine years now, Issa has been selling used items like bags, belts, shoes, caps, etc. With his share of this loan, he will buy more bags, belts and caps to add to his current stock.

loans.use: To buy more bags, belts and caps to add to his current stock

loans.name: Top Up United Group

texts.en: Presented in the photo above are members of the “Top-up United” group from the northern town of Magburaka. They are petty businesspeople who need a loan of SLL 800,000 for each member of the group in order to boost their businesses. Ibrahim B. K., in the middle, is the leader of this group. The 40-year-old is a native of Magburaka town. He is married to a nurse and the couple has three children – two in secondary school and one in primary school. Ibrahim sells “sas man” (local brewed wine), soft drinks, cigarettes, biscuits and much more. He has been a businessman for 13 good years. With his share of the loan, Ibrahim will buy sas man, soft drinks and biscuits at wholesale to add to his business.

loans.use: Buy sas man, soft drinks and biscuits at wholesale to add to his business

loans.name: Tawoprr Group

texts.en: Babah K. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Babah was born in Magburaka town, about 49 years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and he has eight children, all of whom are attending secondary schools. For many years now, Babah has been selling rice, onions, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), tomatoes, toothpaste, toothbrushes, etc. This is the first loan that Babah and his group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Babah will use his share of the loan (SL 1,500,000) to expand his business. He will buy the above-mentioned items at wholesale to add to his current stock.

loans.use: To buy rice, onions, margi, tomatoes, toothpaste, toothbrushes, etc. at wholesale

loans.name: Combine Sisters Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Combine Sisters” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Sallay Papa K. who is pictured on the right. Sallay is approximately 48 year old and was born in Port Loko, northern Sierra Leone. She is married with six children. Her husband is a businessman and two of her children attend school: one is in primary school and the other in college.  Sallay Papa sells dried fish and has been running this business for many years now. She will use her share of the loan to buy baskets full of dried fish. Sallay’s ambition is to make enough profit to be able to build a house for her children.

loans.use: To buy baskets of dried fish

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 26-year-old single man from Lebanon. In 2003, he started working in wall coating and in 2007 he started working in the same field, but on his own. He is now requesting a $1,200 loan to purchase a scaffold to use for the coating of buildings.

loans.use: to purchase a scaffold

loans.name: Bathmorie United Group

texts.en:
This group is named “Bathmorie United”, named after the section in which they live in Magburaka town. The members are all local entrepreneurs in Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a  loan of SLL 800,000 for each from Kiva lenders through SMT.  With the help of this loan, they will be able to improve their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.
 
The group’s leader, Al-Hassan S. B. (pictured in the middle) sells used clothes. Born in Matotoka village, the 59-year-old father of four will use his share of the loan to buy used clothes: jeans, T-Shirts, raincoats, sweaters, etc. With many years of experience in this business, Alhassan carefully selects the type of clothes he buys based on the prevailing season.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Love Each Other Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Love Each Other” group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Hawanatu K. is the leader of this group. The 24-year-old is married to a businessman and they have one child. Hawanatu has been a businesswoman for four years now. She sells rubber bowls, dishes, spoons, cups, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy the abov- mentioned items at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy rubber bowls, dishes, spoons, cups, etc. at wholesale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old single man from Lebanon, living with his parents and three siblings. In 2007, he started his own business in agriculture to further support the family. He is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase needed tools for his business.

loans.use: to purchase needed tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase wood for his work.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 47-year-old married man from Lebanon, living with his wife and two young children. In 1998, he opened his own grocery store, which was then expanded to include chocolate making.

He is now requesting to borrow $2,000 to increase his purchases for the upcoming summer season.

loans.use: to increase his purchases

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome W. M. is thirty-two years old, married, and has two children, age seventeen and five. 

Her business is located by the roadside at Dandora estate in Nairobi. She sells clothes to the local people and passersby. She has been in this business for the last ten years and she says that the business is good and profitable. The only challenge is that there are so many doing the same kind of business as hers and so customers are spoiled by so many choices. 

She is using her loan of 40,000 KES to buy more trousers, shirts and skirts. She hopes to grow her business and even be able to import clothes and sell in the country. She is hardworking, courageous and optimistic.

loans.use: To buy jeans, shirts and skirts to sell

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en:
Haidar is a 46-year-old Lebanese borrower. He is married and the father of one child. 

Haidar has been working in the field of construction for 20 years now. He works on a freelance basis, taking on housing projects and other projects such as building shops. He has many years of experience and is very proud of the work he provides. He has been able to build networking and a good reputation among his clients. His clients can be people from his region, as well as larger construction projects. 

Today, for the first time, Haidar has asked for a loan from the Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase steel beams for his work.

loans.use: To purchase steel beams for his work.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 23-year-old single man from Lebanon, who lives with his parents and two siblings. In 2007, he started his own cellular phone business after having two years experience in the field.

He is now hoping to purchase new accessories for the phones and to do so he will need to borrow $1,200.

loans.use: To purchase new accessories for the phones

loans.name: Habib

texts.en:
Habib is a 49-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and their two children.

He has been working in the construction industry since 1988. He has been running his own business for this period of time. He is extremely proud of his reputation and experience, but when he first started he had difficulty building his business and making himself known, which is a demanding job in his region. In his work, he completes all components of a construction project. 

Today, Habib is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. He plans to purchase scaffolding for his work. This will be his first loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase scaffolding for his work.

loans.name: Chadi

texts.en:
Chadi is a 22-year-old single man from Lebanon. Chadi has owned an electronics and home products shop since 2007. Chadi is proud of the high quality of his work. 

Today, Chadi, for the first time, is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase merchandise and install new stands in his shop. He hopes to keep on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and install new stands in his shop.

loans.name: Awadhi

texts.en:
Awadhi is a married woman with a young child. She has been operating her charcoal business for one year and sells at all levels - as wholesale, retail, door to door, and from home to her neighbors and food vendors. With the 30,000 KES she wants to buy five sacks of charcoal. Her husband works as a driver and he supports the family financially.

Awadhi hopes to be the main supplier in the entire market in the future and to have three more branches. Her greatest monthly expense is food. She owns a home with electricity but no piped water. She decided to work with Yehu so as to get a loan and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy five sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old single man from Lebanon. In 2006, he started working on his own in the agriculture business after four years of experience in the field.

He is now requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase equipment for the business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 60-year-old married man from Lebanon. He is a father of twelve children. He has been working since 1980 as a home painter, and he also owns a grocery store where he sells canned food, groceries, candies, beverages, biscuits and lots more. His clients are people from his region and its surroundings. Ibrahim says that he is committed to both his businesses and is proud of his experience. He notes that it has been a challenge to secure financing for both his businesses. Today, for the second time, Ibrahim is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to install stands in his shop. Ibrahim works hard to provide the best for his big family.

loans.use: To install stands in his shop

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is married. She has a kiosk in Kherson city selling various items: dishes, pots, cosmetics and some clothing. Olena started this business about 10 years ago. At that time she lost her job and needed a source of income. She knew some friends who were already involved in a sales business. She decided to try and the attempt was successful! 

Today Olena has many customers and always offers them good quality products at affordable prices. Her large variety of items allows Olena to have the same level of income throughout the different seasons. Olena has taken out small business loans before and found them to be a good aid for her business. This time Olena would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to purchase more inventory and increase her assortment of goods.

loans.use: to purchase inventory

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 43-year-old man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and their six children. Since 2006, Hussein has been working as a drinkable water distributor and supplier in his town. He's very famous in his town and known by his good reputation. He has a good number of clients who are from his region.

Today, Hussein is asking for a loan to purchase a water fill machine. This is his third cycle, and he has always paid on time. His previous loans allowed him to purchase water coolers for his project. He's planning to improve his work and expand his business into other areas.

loans.use: To purchase a water fill machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To change the decor of his shop

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married man from Lebanon. In 2002 he opened his own grocery store but mainly sold gas tanks for houses. He is now requesting a loan of $1,500 to increase his purchases.

loans.use: To increase his purchases

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 53-year-old married man from Lebanon who is the father of seven children. He runs a taxi business and has over 28 years of experience as a driver. In Lebanon, it is common to use taxi services to go between neighborhoods in a given town as well as to travel between different regions. These services are especially important in areas where the infrastructure is less developed, which is true for most of the towns outside of Beirut and its suburbs. 

Today, Hassan is asking for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to buy a new car for his business. His previous loan allowed him to perform much- needed maintenance work on his taxi’s engine and body so that he could continue to offer comfortable transportation service to his customers.

loans.use: To buy a new car for his taxi business.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 47-year old married man from Lebanon who lives with his wife and four young children. He has owned his own grocery store for the past 12 years, and is now asking to borrow $1,200 to buy merchandise for the store.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell to his customers

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en:
Rabih is a 32-year-old Lebanese entrepreneur who lives with his wife and their five children. In 2005, he decided to open a restaurant where he sells chicken cooked in various ways, including in sandwiches and roasted. His restaurant is well-known for its good food and great location in the middle of the town. 

Today, for the first time, Rabih is requesting a loan to buy a refrigerator and to wire the electricity in his restaurant. His plans for the future include continuing to improve his business and the service he provides to his customers.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator and electrical wiring for his restaurant.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 41-year-old married Lebanese man who is the father of four children. Since 1995, he has made a living working in construction. He is now very experienced in this field and very proud from the work he performs. He works as a freelancer, taking on housing and other projects such as building shops. When he first started his business, he had difficulty building a network of contacts and clients, because this is demanding work and there is lots of competition. But he built a good reputation among his clients and in his part of Lebanon. 

Ali is applying for a loan from Kiva partner A. Majmoua to buy steel beams to use on various projects. This is his second loan, and he has successfully repaid his previous loan on time. This first loan allowed him to buy tools to use when working on his projects.

loans.use: To buy steel beams for a construction business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 53-year-old married Lebanese man who is the father of five children. Since 1995, he has made a living raising livestock, and he is now able to produce enough milk from his cattle to sell much of it to his customers. Ali is requesting a loan from the Kiva partner Al Majmoua to buy a cow so that he an increase his production of milk. This is his first loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To buy a cow to increase his production of milk

loans.name: Amer

texts.en: Amer is a 32 year old single man from Lebanon. Since 2003, Amer has been working in the field of construction. Therefore, he has many years of experience and is very proud from the work he provides. He works on a freelance basis, taking housing projects and other projects such as building shops, and more. When he first started his business, he notes that it was a challenge to secure financing for both his businesses. His clients can be people from his region, as well as construction projects. Today, for the first time, Amer has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase wood, tools and steel beams for his work. He hopes to keep on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase wood, tools and steel beams for his work.

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is married with two adult children. She has a small business selling bed linen, pajamas, and bath robes at the central market in Kahovka town. Olena started this business 22 years ago. This business has been the main source of income for Olena's family, allowing her to raise her children and provide for her family's needs.

Today she has 3 small locations that sell inventories. She works at one location herself and provides work for two more people. Olena would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to increase the assortment of goods. She has used small business loans before and found them very instrumental for her business development.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of goods.

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.es:
El Sr. Rodolfo A.  es cliente recurrente, es casado y vive en casa propia.
El titular realiza trabajos de albañilería hace mas de 15 años,  a la vez tiene con su ganancias de su trabajo como albañil esposa un negocio donde invierte las ganancias que obtiene con su trabajo como albañil.
El negocio es administrada por su esposa y así se ayudan mutuamente para salir adelante.
El solicita un préstamo para la compra de algunas herramienta que facilitara su trabajo albañil como una mezcladora.
texts.en:
Mr. Rodolfo A. is a returning client. He is married and he lives in his own house. He has been working in masonry for over 15 years. Meanwhile, with his earnings from his work as a mason, his wife opened a business where they continue to invest money earned in his work. The business is run by his wife and as such helps them both to move ahead. He is soliciting a loan in order to buy some tools which will facilitate his work as a mason, such as a mixer.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a mixer and other tools for masonry.

loans.name: Hamad

texts.en:
Hamad is a 34 year old married man from Lebanon. He loves with his wife and their five children. He has been working as an electrician since 1996. His main customers are local community members. He says that his experience in this field of work has allowed him to remain competitive and successful. When he first started his business, he had difficulty building a network, since there is lots of competition. Since he is a hard working man, he was able to build a good reputation among his clients and make himself known in his region.
  
Today, Hamad is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, Kiva partner to buy electrical wires and tools for his work. This will be his first loan from Al Majmoua and he plans to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy electrical wires and tools for his work.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 26 year old single man from Lebanon. Ahmad had been running a painting business for five years now. He is skilled in painting homes. He says that he is very committed to his work and proud of his experience. He says that finding better ways to advertise his business has been a challenge. Ahmad is a hardworking man who does his best to make himself known and satisfy his clients' demands.

He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, Kiva partner. He plans to buy paints and electrical wires for his work. This is his second loan from Al Majmoua. His previous loan allowed him to improve his work. He hopes to further expand his business in the future.

loans.use: To buy paints and also electrical wires for his work.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is 28 year old single man from Lebanon. Mohamad has been selling groceries from his van for a year now. He is a mobile grocery salesman. He travels in his town and meets with local community clients. His most popular products are snacks, juices and beverages, cigarettes, candies and chips.

Mohamad says that his experience in trading is why he decided on doing his job. When he first started, he encountered some financial issues and couldn't diversify his merchandise. Today, for the first time, he is asking for a loan to change his van, as he wants to have a bigger and better one for his work. He hopes that it will allow him to improve his financial situation. He hopes in the future, to improve his work.

loans.use: To change his van.

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en:
Youssef is a 22 year old single man from Lebanon. Since 2006, he has been working in the field of industry. He is specialized in installing and repairing tiles, as well as polishing them. This type of business is very common in Lebanon. When he first started his business, he had some financial issues which didn't allow him to purchase all the needed tools for his work. Youssef is known for his good work and is proud of his experience. 

Today, for the first time, Youssef is asking for a loan to purchase a generator for his business, since in lebabon there is a lot of electricity shut downs. If he doesn't have a generator, it will stop him from working and, therefore, it will delay his work and his clients will be unsatisfied. Therefore, he hopes that it will help him continue to grow and enhance his business in the coming year.

loans.use: To purchase a generator for his business.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David M. K. is twenty-four years old, married and has two children aged between the age of twelve years old and six months old. His business is located at Kamkunji in Nairobi. Nairobi is the capital city of Kenya.

He owns a restaurant in which he sells food to the local people. He has been in this business for the last five years. He says that this business is profitable, but the major challenge is that there are so many people in the area doing the same kind of business as his and so the customers are not loyal as they are spoiled by choice. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy food items to make food to sell to his customers. He describes himself as hardworking, ambitious and focused.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make food for his restaurant.

loans.name: Mehsen

texts.en:
Mehsen is a 47 year old entrepreneur from Lebanon. He is a father of four children. Mehsen has owned and operated a grocery store for a year. He decided on opening his store, because he wanted to improve his family's financial situation. He sells canned food, groceries, candies, chips, biscuits, juices, beverages and much more.

For the first time, Mehsen is asking for a loan from Al Majmoua, Kiva partner, to purchase merchandise and a fridge for ice cream. His loan will allow him to increase his stock, and therefore improve his income. He hopes to continue to improve his business in the coming year.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and a fridge for ice cream.

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal is 47 years old and married with five children. Chantal’s husband is a driver and Chantal herself is a businesswoman. Both of them work for their family profit. Chantal owns a small business selling various styles of clothes in her living place. She employs one person from her community as a helper and the hours of her business are ten hours per day except on Saturday. This is her sixth year of successful business operation.

Chantal is now requesting a second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business by purchasing bales of clothes. This loan will allow her to attract more customers, which will help her earn more profit. With this profit, Chantal will be able to renovate her house and save money for her future.

loans.use: To buy bales of clothes

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en:
Bassam is a 50 year old borrower from Lebanon. He is married and is a father of three children. Bassam has been working in bee keeping and agriculture.

Today, for the first time, Bassam is requesting a loan to plant a new orchard. He decided to start his businesses because of his experience. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his work, and hopes to expand his agriculture business.

loans.use: To plant a new orchard.

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick O. O. is married and has three children between the ages of eight and one. His business is located at Kamkunji in Nairobi. He is a blacksmith who makes cookers, metal boxes, and other items. He sells the items to the local people. He has been in this business for the last nine years. He says that this business is profitable, but the major challenge is the high cost of raw materials. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well.

He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy materials to make more items to grow his business. He describes himself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Ezechiel

texts.en:
Ezechiel is 30 years old and married with a one-year-old child.  Ezechiel is commonly known for his business of selling clothes for women and this is his fifth successful year in this business.  The hours of his business are from 9 am to 6 pm every day.

Ezechiel is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business by purchasing additional styles of clothes to sell.  With this loan, Ezechiel will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow him to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To purchase of additional styles of clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy rocks, crushing process equipment such as diggers, shovels and used tires, and to pay workers

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 33 year old single womman from Lebanon, living with her parents and two siblings. She has owned a photocopy center for the past three years.

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase a new photocopy machine to attend to her clients' needs.

loans.use: To purchase a new photocopy machine.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 50 year old married woman from Lebanon, living with her three children, who help and support her. For the past 20 years she has been working in the sales of provisions.

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 32 year old married man from Lebanon, living with his wife and young child. Fourteen years ago, he started working with his friend as a hairdresser. In 2007, he opened hs own salon.

He is now requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase products for the salon.

loans.use: To purchase products.

loans.name: Zindzy

texts.en:
Zindzy has been operating her open air food stall for one year. She is married to a businessman, and has three children:  two boys and a girl and they all attend school. With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to buy a sack of beans, cooking oil, Irish potatoes and baking flour.

Zindzy sells from home to her neighbors and passersby, citing competition as her major challenge in the business. She hopes to run a big restaurant in future. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees, electricity and food. Zindzy decided to work with Yehu to get a loan and improve her living standards. She owns a house with electricity but no piped water.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of beans, Irish potatoes,cooking oil and baking flour.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 45 year old married man from Lebanon, living with his wife and three young children. In 2003, he opened his own café after working in the field for 3 years.

He is now requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase an LCD projector for the cafe in order to attract more clients with the World Cup season.

loans.use: To purchase an LCD projector.

loans.name: Antony

texts.en:
Antony is a member of Prosper group in Faulu Kenya. He sells shoes and saves part of his income with the group. He started this business five years ago, after he left his job as a casual laborer. He gets more income from the business than from his previous job. He also does quarrying for more income. Antony’s living standard has improved and he bought a motorbike for transporting his goods.

With the loan of Kes.50,000, he plans to add to his stock of shoes. Antony is married and blessed with two children.

loans.use: To add shoes for sale.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es:
La Sra. Elsa P. tiene 59 años, es soltera cuenta tiene un hijo  a quien cuida ella sola.  
Ella se dedica a la venta de varioa productos como joyas, sabanas, lencería y otros por toda la ciudad recorriendo a pie, también ofrece sus mercaderías en los buces y en varios negocios, la mayoría de sus clientes son docentes quienes le pagan en cuotas.  
Su objetivo es alquilar un local para ofrecer sus mercaderías ya que es muy sacrificado recorrer las calles  para vender y además  daría una mejor atención a sus clientes.  
Ella solicita el préstamo para la compra de sabanas, colchas, lencerías, joyas, calzados, perfumes de varias marcas.
texts.en:
Sra. Elsa Pasmore, 59, is single and has one son for whom she is responsible. She operates a business selling various products: jewelry, bedding, tablecloths and other similar merchandise. She works as a street vendor, going all around the city on foot. She also sells on buses and at some businesses. Most of her customers are teachers who pay for what they buy a little at a time. Sra. Elsa wants to rent a shop where she can establish her business because working as a street vendor is too physically demanding for her. A shop would also allow her to provide a better service to her customers. Sra. Elsa is applying for a loan to buy various products--sheets, bedding, tableclothes, jewelry, footwear, perfumes--that she will resell.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to resell.

loans.name: Lokumu Plus Group

texts.en:
Jeanine M. is the leader of the Community Bank named "Lokumu Plus" which means "Honor" in English. It is composed of 26 members united in solidarity for receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Jeanine has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 2002. She runs two general stores to the Southwest of Kinshasa. She has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills in order to realize her dream of one day opening a large clothing shop in her area. She would also like to achieve financial independence through her business that earns her $200 per week. She works to the best of her abilities and uses her contacts so that she might achieve her goals.

Jeanine is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having five times obtained and correctly repaid loans. She will increase her stock of merchandise with her next loan by buying 80 boxes of eggs and reselling them at a profit. Jeanine is married and the mother of two children, whose ages are 23 and 24 years old.

loans.use: To purchase 80 boxes of eggs to resell at a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 39 year old single man from Lebanon, living with his parents. In 2002, he opened his own mini market to attend to the needs of the residents in the surrounding areas.

He is now requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase merchandise for the store.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31 year old married man from Lebanon. He opened his own dental clinic in 2007 and is still expanding it to attract new clients.
He is requesting to borrow $1,200 in order to purchase a new teeth whitening machine.

loans.use: To purchase a new teeth whitening machine.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 27 year old single man from Lebanon. He has been a fisherman for the past ten years; he started it as a hobby and then it became his source of income when he started selling the fish in 2004.

He is now requesting to borrow $1,000 in order to buy a new fishing net for the business.

loans.use: To buy a new fishing net.

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
El Sr.  Victor tiene 36 años es soltero sin hijos,culmino sus estudios secundarios.
El tuvo que viajar a España ya que no tenia trabajo y con los ahorroas de su trabajo el volvio a Paraguay y pudo invertir en la apertura de un Cyber, actualmente cuenta con 3 locales propios y desea abril otro por lo que solicita el crédito para la compra de mas computadoras.
texts.en:
Victor, 36, is single and childless; he completed secondary education. Due to unemployment he went to Spain to work. With his savings he returned to Paraguay and was able to invest in a Cybercafe. He currently owns three locales and wants to open another one, thus the loan request to purchase more computers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy computers.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 35-year old married man. He started working in the agriculture business 15 years ago.
He is now requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase needed goods for his business.

loans.use: To purchase needed agricultural goods

loans.name: Kimenyedde Womens Group, Kayunga

texts.en:
N. Racheal at 60 years is still active at effectively seeing to it that her retail business outlet in Malyangalyanga, Kayunga, is operating successfully. It’s a business she began when she was still on the sunny side of 30 and, amazingly, it’s still going strong, notwithstanding the many challenges that have reared their heads.

Racheal’s success story has made other people in her village strive to emulate her. It’s now 42 years down the road and her unwavering business spirit does not look like it’s getting frail any time soon. Instead, she has been emboldened more by the fact that she has managed to survive this long despite the fact that she operates in a rural setting.

Racheal is a widow whose determination to educate all her seven children has never wavered. As a result, all of them are in good schools around Kayunga. In a month, she makes profits to the tune of 400,000 shillings and, with this loan, she is hoping she will have the leverage to purchase more items for her retail shop: items like bags of sugar and salt, bars of soap, basins, cups and many more items that her clients have an inclination for.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items such as bags of sugar and salt and many more items

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 33-year old married man from Lebanon, living with his wife and three young children. In 2003, he started working in the construction industry by trading in cement.
He is now requesting a loan for $1,200 to purchase wood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase wood

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 60-year old married woman from Lebanon, living with her husband and two children. Twenty years ago she started working in a pastry store and at the age of 58 she took the risk and started her own business. Her husband purchased a store for her to sell her home-made pastries.
She is now requesting a loan of $1,000  to purchase inventory for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her pastry shop

loans.name: Kivelyo

texts.en: Kivelyo J. M. is a single woman who has been operating her scrap metal business for one year. Her previous occupation was selling  second hand clothes. Kivelyo sells at a shop to people within the town but she faces the challenge of thieves and seasonality. Kivelyo rents a house with electricity and piped water, citing rent as her greatest monthly expense. Kivelyo decided to join Yehu  to get a loan with a low interest rate and to improve her living standard. With the Kshs 80,000 loan she is requesting, she would like to purchase more scrap metal and also to pay unskilled labor. In the future, Kivelyo would like to buy her own plot and to  build a shop so as to minimize her rent expenses and to make more business profit.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal and pay unskilled labour.

loans.name: Santa Fe Group

texts.es:
En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer Panamericana, se reúne la Asociación Comunal SANTA FE
Su presidenta es la señora Marisol P. de 30 años, ella tiene una tienda de abarrotes (arroz, fideo, azucar, harina y otros) en su domicilio, el cual atiende todos los días de 6 de la mañana a 9 de la noche, le colabora en el negocio su hermana. Con el préstamo tiene planificado comprar arroz y fideo que son los productos que mayor demanda tienen. 
Las demás integrantes de ésta Asociación tienen diferentes negocios y necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería, insumos o materia prima, según el negocio que tengan.
texts.en:
The SANTA FE communal bank meets in one of Pro Mujer Panamericana’s focus centers. The group president is Marisol P., 30. She has a grocery store (rice, pasta, sugar, flour, etc) in her home. She is open for business every day from 6am until 9pm; her sister helps out. She plans to use the funds to buy rice and pasta which are the items that have the most demand. The other group members have a variety of businesses and need the funds to buy merchandise, ingredients or raw materials according to the type of business each has.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 56-year old married man from Lebanon, living with his wife and two children. In 2000, he opened his own pastries store. His customers come from the surrounding areas.
He is now requesting a loan of $1,200 in order to purchase needed goods for his shop.

loans.use: To purchase needed goods

loans.name: Bladimir

texts.es:
Don Bladimir es un padre de familia de dos hijos, hombre dedicado al trabajo, de profesión contador, el cual ejerció por varios años y con su liquidación formo su propio negocio una pulpería en donde con su esposa trabajan en conjunto para dar un mejor servicio y apoyarse mutuamente para un mejor porvenir para sus hijos.
Desde horas temprana abren su negocio para aprovechar la mañana que se vende, aunque no siempre están buenas las ventas unos días mejores que otro. 
Es por eso trata de vender productos rotativos para sus clientes, y mover más su capital, con este financiamiento lograra aumentar en productos como: golosinas, gaseosas, productos enlatados, jugos, carne, pollo, pan y otros que se vendan día  a día.
Para el ha sido de gran beneficios estos financiamiento, ya que ha logrado el equilibrio de su negocio, aumentado sus ventas, y mejores utilidades.
texts.en:
Mr. Bladimir is the father of two kids, he is dedicated to work, he is an accountant, and worked on his profession for several years and with his severance he started his own business, a grocery store in which he and his wife work in order to improve their service and help each other to improve their kids' future. They open their business early in the morning to start selling soon, although sales are not always good, some days are better than others. This is why he tries to diversify products for his clients, and move more his capital, with this loan he will be able to increase products like: candy, sodas, canned products, juices, meat, poultry, bread and others that sell day by day. These loans have been very beneficial to him, because he has been able to balance his business, increasing sales and improving his profit.

Translated from Spanish by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy candy, sodas, canned products, juices, meat, poultry, bread and other products to improve sales

loans.name: Mwanamkasi

texts.en: Mwanamkasi H. has been operating her food stall for the last two years. She sells at an open air market nearby her home where neighbors and passersby are mainly her customers. Mwanamkasi is happily married with three children, two boys and a girl, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a taxi driver and supports the family and their daily basic needs. They rent a home with no electricity nor piped water. Mwanamkas is requesting a loan of Ksh 40,000 to purchase 250kgs of Irish potatoes, baking flour, cooking oil and one sack of charcoal.  Her main challenges in the business are seasonality and competition as many people have ventured into the same business. Mwanamkasi would like to build her own home in the future.

loans.use: To purchase 250kgs of Irish potatoes, baking flour,cooking oil, and one sack of charcoal .

loans.name: Paz En La Tormenta Group

texts.es:
En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer Panamericana, se reúne la Asociación Comunal PAZ EN LA TORMENTA, con 8 integrantes. 
Una de las integrantes y presidenta  es María F. H., de 43 años, se dedica desde hace 20 años al tejido de prendas de vestir. Compra su materia prima de la feria 16 de Julio y vende en la misma feria los productos terminados, tiene 6 hijos a los cuales saca adelante con los ingresos del negocio. Maria necesita el préstamo para comprar materia prima como la lana.  
Las demás integrantes de éste grupo cuentan con diversos negocios y necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería, insumos o materia prima, según el negocio que tengan.
texts.en:
The PAZ EN LA TORMENTA (Peace within the Storm) communal bank has 8 members and meets in one of Pro Mujer Panamericana’s focal centers. One of the group members is María F. H., 43. She has woven clothing items for 20 years. She buys her raw materials at the 16 de Julio market and sells her finished items there as well. She has 6 children who she supports with income from her business. María needs the loan to buy raw materials like wool. The other group members have a variety of businesses and need funds to buy merchandise, ingredients or raw materials according to the type of business each has.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wool.

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
Este comité se formo mediante el deseo de las señoras de trabajar en grupo con ayuda mutua entre ellas.
Una de las integrantes es la señora  Francisca quien  es ama de casa ella trabaja en su casa y atiende a sus hijos, al mismo tiempo ella atiende el negocio que tiene en su casa.
Ella comenta que está muy contenta con el grupo, y desea seguir trabajando para fortalecer el comité.
Ella solicita el crédito para invertir en la compra de los productos que solicitan sus clientes que en general son de consumo familiar como harina, arroz, panificados, lácteos, y otros.
texts.en:
This committee was formed due to the desire of the women to work together and help each other. One of the group members is Francisca who is a housewife; she cares for her home and children but at the same time tends to her home-based business. She states that she is very happy with the group and wants to continue working to strengthen the group. She is asking for funds to buy the products that her customers most request: flour, rice, baked goods, dairy products, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flour, pasta, sugar, rice, baked goods, dairy products, etc.

loans.name: Kyampisi Development Group, Kayunga

texts.en:
M. Joseph is a 70-year-old with eight children. He operates a poultry and pig husbandry business in Kyampisi in Kayunga. This business has been in existence for the last fifteen years and he began it with savings from his earlier produce sales. He has also been eking out profits from his rental business.

In a week, this hardworking man makes 30,000 shillings and, with this loan, he wants to buy goats, chickens and piglets that he will raise and later resell.

loans.use: To purchase chickens, piglets and goats to raise and sell

loans.name: San Juan De San Roque Group

texts.es:
En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer Panamericana, se reúne la Asociación Comunal SAN JUAN DE SAN ROQUE, con 8 integrantes 

Una de las integrantes es Justa L. de 37 años, es casada y madre de 6 niños. Ella se dedica al tejido de  prendas de vestir y vende en Desaguadero. En esta oportunidad necesita el préstamo para comprar hilos y tejer mantas. 
Las demás integrantes de éste grupo cuentan con variados negocios como la venta de material escolar, comida, condimentos, verduras, víveres, cosméticos y abarrotes.
texts.en:
The SAN JUAN DE SAN ROQUE communal bank has 8 members and meets in one of Pro Mujer Panamericana’s focus centers. One of the group members is Justa L., 37. She is married and has 6 children. She weaves clothing items to sell in Desaguadero. She is asking for funds to buy yarn with which to weave blankets. The other group members have a variety of sales businesses such as: school supplies, food, spices, vegetable, groceries, cosmetics and prepared meals.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials (yarn).
